metadata.description: Unified Validation Database combining Bluebook, Redbook, Tables, and Individual Rules

1.rule_title: Structure and Use of Citations - Signals
1.rule_text: Provide citations to authorities so that readers may identify and find those authorities for future research. Citations are made in citation sentences and clauses (rule 1.1) and are introduced by signals. Signals organize authorities and show how those authorities support or relate to a proposition given in the text (rule 1.2).

sub_rules.title: Citation Sentences and Clauses
sub_rules.description: A citation sentence is an independent sentence devoted entirely to citations. A citation clause is a series of citations, separated by semicolons when of the same signal type, that is embedded within a sentence.

sub_rules.title: Introductory Signals
sub_rules.description: Signals introduce citations and indicate the degree of support the cited authority provides for the proposition. They are classified as supportive, comparative, contradictory, or background signals.

sub_rules.title: Order of Signals
sub_rules.description: When multiple signals are used, they appear in a specific order: supportive signals first, then comparative, then contradictory, then background signals.

sub_rules.title: Order of Authorities Within Each Signal
sub_rules.description: Authorities within each signal are separated by semicolons and ordered by importance or helpfulness.

sub_rules.title: Parenthetical Information
sub_rules.description: Explanatory parentheticals may follow citations to clarify relevance, but are not allowed after 'See generally' or standalone 'Cf.'

sub_rules.title: Related Authority
sub_rules.description: Subsequent history and related authority should not be given parenthetically but through explanatory phrases.

supportive.usage: Use when the cited authority is an example of the stated rule
Use when authority states or supports the proposition but was not the source of the proposition
Use when authority directly supports the proposition
Use for authorities with somewhat less direct support than 'See'

supportive.meaning: Indicates useful comparison with some explanation
supportive.usage: Use when comparison between authorities supports the proposition

comparative.usage: Use to introduce first element of comparison

contradictory.usage: Use when authority directly states or clearly supports a contrary proposition
Use when comparison with authority supports a contrary proposition

background.usage: Use for authorities providing helpful background or context

formatting_requirements: Signals in roman type (NOT italicized) in citations
Space between signal and first citation
Multiple sources with same signal separated by semicolons
Different signal types in different citation sentences
Capitalize signals at sentence start
No parenthetical explanation after 'See generally'
No parenthetical explanation after standalone 'Cf.'
Compare/contrast signals use semicolons between paired authorities
All sources include year in parentheses
Period at end of citation sentence

correct_regex_patterns.description: Match semicolon separation of same-type signals

error_regex_patterns.description: Parenthetical after See generally or Cf.
Comma instead of semicolon between same signals

examples.explanation: Signal in roman type, proper spacing, period at end, year included

examples.text: See Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020); accord Brown v. Green, 234 U.S. 567 (2019).
examples.explanation: Multiple sources with same signal type separated by semicolon

examples.text: Compare Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020), with Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973).
examples.explanation: Compare...with structure with comma before 'with'
Signal italicized (should be roman type in citations)

examples.text: See Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020) (explaining the doctrine).
examples.explanation: Explanatory parenthetical with regular See signal

examples.text: See generally Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020) (discussing background).
examples.explanation: Parenthetical not allowed after See generally

exceptions: Signals used as verbs in text should be italicized: 'This analysis *sees* the problem differently'
When signal is used as a verb, separate multiple sources with semicolons
Compare/contrast signals use semicolons between paired authorities
In textual material (not citations), signals may have different formatting rules

2.rule_text: Legal writing uses four typefaces, though choice of typeface conventions differs between academic writing (Whitepages) and practitioner documents (Bluepages). In law review footnotes, specific typefaces are used for different citation elements: ordinary roman, italics, SMALL CAPS, and LARGE & SMALL CAPS.

sub_rules.title: Typeface Conventions for Law Review Citations (Whitepages)
sub_rules.description: In academic writing, citations use four typefaces: roman, italics, small caps, and large & small caps.

sub_rules.title: Typeface Conventions for Textual Material (Whitepages)
sub_rules.description: In the main text of academic writing, only roman and italics are available.

sub_rules.title: Underlined Type (Bluepages)
sub_rules.description: Court documents use underlining instead of italics in limited contexts.

sub_rules.title: Bolded Type (Bluepages)
sub_rules.description: Bold is used extremely rarely in court documents, only in extraordinary circumstances.

sub_rules.title: Italics and Punctuation
sub_rules.description: Punctuation is italicized only if immediately adjacent to italicized words.

italics_in_citations.periodical_titles: Use SMALL CAPS instead in Whitepages (e.g., STAN. L. REV.)
italics_in_citations.signals_in_citations: Roman type (NOT italicized): See, Accord, Cf., etc.

small_caps_in_citations.note: SMALL CAPS appear ONLY in Whitepages (law review), never in Bluepages

roman_type_in_citations.signals: See, Accord, Cf., But see, See generally, etc.
roman_type_in_citations.court_document_titles: Brief for Petitioner, Motion in Limine

formatting_requirements: Case names italicized in all contexts (Whitepages)
Book titles italicized (Whitepages) or roman/underline (Bluepages)
Periodical names in SMALL CAPS (Whitepages) or roman (Bluepages)
Institutional author names in SMALL CAPS (Whitepages) or roman (Bluepages)
Signals in roman type (except when used as verbs)
Punctuation italicized ONLY if immediately adjacent to italicized word
No italicization if space between word and punctuation
No bold in Whitepages citations
Minimal underlining in Bluepages
Consistent formatting throughout document

correct_regex_patterns.description: Match signals in roman type (not italicized)

error_regex_patterns.description: Punctuation outside italics when should be inside

examples.explanation: Case name italicized, signal in roman, proper punctuation

examples.text: See John Hart Ely, *Democracy and Distrust* 4-5 (1980).
examples.explanation: Book title italicized, proper citation format
Periodical name in small caps (Whitepages)
Signal should not be italicized in citation context
Space between case name and comma breaks adjacency

exceptions: Signals used as verbs in text are italicized: *This analysis sees the issue*
Blue Pages use roman primarily with minimal special formatting
Case names may use underline instead of italics in Blue Pages
Punctuation in block quotations may have different rules
URLs and special content may have different formatting

4.rule_text: After a full citation has been provided, subsequent citations to the same authority may use a short form. Three main approaches: (1) Id. for identical references, (2) Supra for previous references (except cases), and (3) case name short forms or author short forms.

sub_rules.title: Id. for Identical References
sub_rules.description: Use 'Id.' when the immediately preceding citation is to the sole authority.

sub_rules.title: Supra for Previous References
sub_rules.description: Use 'Supra' for authorities previously cited (except cases) with the note number.

sub_rules.title: Short Forms by Citation Type
sub_rules.description: Different citation types use different short form conventions.

sub_rules.title: Hereinafter Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Use 'hereinafter' sparingly for cumbersome titles or multiple works by same author.

id_form.usage: Use when immediately preceding citation is the sole authority
id_form.scope: Same footnote OR immediately following footnote ONLY

supra_form.usage: For previously cited authority (not in immediately preceding footnote)
supra_form.typical_uses: Secondary sources, legislative materials, books, articles, unpublished sources
supra_form.restriction: Cases do NOT use supra - use case name short form instead
valid_examples: Smith, Article Title, supra note 10, at 50
invalid_examples: Smith v. Jones, supra note 5 (cases NOT allowed)

allowed: Case name with reporter: Roe, 410 U.S. 113
Case name with pinpoint: Roe, 410 U.S. at 116
Id. (if immediately preceding is same case)

hereinafter_form.usage: Authority with cumbersome name OR multiple works by same author
hereinafter_form.use_frequency: SPARINGLY (only when supra would be confusing)
hereinafter_form.format: ('Full Title', hereinafter 'Short') then Short, supra note [X]
hereinafter_form.default_approach: Default to supra unless confusion would result
valid_examples: ('United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea', hereinafter 'UNCLOS')

formatting_requirements: Id. must refer to immediately preceding citation
Id. must include 'at' when using pinpoint page
Supra includes note number: supra note X
Supra not allowed for cases
Hereinafter should be used very sparingly
Hereinafter defined in first full citation
Case name short forms omit first names
Case name short forms may use reporter citations
Author short forms use last name only
Capitalization maintained for short forms

correct_regex_patterns.description: Match Id. short form with optional pinpoint
Match supra short form for books/articles

examples.explanation: Valid short form for identical preceding citation
Id. with pinpoint page number
Supra short form for book with pinpoint
Case name short form alone
Case short form with pinpoint

exceptions: Cases use case name short forms, not supra
Hereinafter abbreviations only for cumbersome titles
Id. cannot refer to sources cited only in parentheticals
Multiple works by same author may need title in short form
Some courts have specific local short form rules

6.rule_text: The Bluebook provides comprehensive abbreviation rules for legal citations across multiple tables. Rule 6 governs abbreviations for case names, reporters, jurisdictions, court names, and other legal materials. Key tables include T1 (federal courts/materials), T2 (state courts), T6 (corporate designations), and T10 (geographical terms).

sub_rules.title: Case Name Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate case names per Table T1, omitting first/middle names and 'The' at start.

sub_rules.title: Court Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate court names per Table T1 (federal) and T2 (state).

sub_rules.title: Reporter Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate case reporters per Table T1, including official and unofficial reporters.

sub_rules.title: Geographic Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate geographic terms per Table T10.

sub_rules.title: Institutional Author Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate institutional authors per Table T3.

case_names.omit_first_names: Use: Smith v. Jones (NOT: John Smith v. Mary Jones)
case_names.omit_the: Use: Blue Cross v. State (NOT: The Blue Cross v. State)
case_names.use_acronyms: NLRB v. Smith (use widely known acronyms)
case_names.abbreviate_designations: Use Table T6 (Co., Inc., Ltd., Corp., etc.)
case_names.omit_other_parties: List only first party on each side of v.

federal_reporters.supreme_court: U.S., S. Ct., L. Ed., U.S.L.W.
federal_reporters.district_courts: F. Supp., F. Supp. 2d, F. Supp. 3d, F.R.D.
federal_reporters.specialized: B.R., Fed. Cl., Ct. Int'l Trade

state_codes.cal: Cal. Code or Cal. Penal Code
state_codes.note: See Table T1 for complete list

formatting_requirements: Use standard abbreviations from Tables T1-T21
Omit first and middle names from party names
Omit 'The' as first word of party name
Abbreviate corporate designations per Table T6
Use state abbreviations per Table T10
Include periods in abbreviations (e.g., U.S.C., not USC)
Capitalize abbreviations appropriately (S. Ct., not s. ct.)
Use abbreviations only in citations, not in full text
No spaces in some abbreviations (F.2d not F. 2d)
Follow specific rules for agency abbreviations

error_regex_patterns.description: 'The' should be omitted from party names
Corporate designations should be abbreviated with periods

examples.explanation: Proper abbreviations with periods, no first names

examples.text: The Blue Cross v. State, 234 F.3d 567 (2nd Cir. 2019)
examples.explanation: 'The' should be omitted from party name

examples.text: General Motors Corp. v. Johnson, 345 U.S. 678 (2018)
examples.explanation: Corporate designation abbreviated per Table T6

exceptions: Well-known abbreviations may be used in text (e.g., NLRB)
Some state codes use full names instead of abbreviations

Local court rules may have specific abbreviation requirements
Some abbreviations differ between Whitepages and Bluepages

8.rule_text: Specific capitalization rules apply to constitutional amendments, acts, court names, judicial titles, and legal documents. The Bluebook provides detailed guidance on when to capitalize references and when to use lowercase to distinguish specific entities from generic references.

sub_rules.title: Constitutional Amendments
sub_rules.description: Capitalize specific constitutional amendments but not generic amendment references.

sub_rules.title: Acts and Statutes
sub_rules.description: Capitalize specific act and statute names but not generic statute references.

sub_rules.title: Court and Judge References
sub_rules.description: Specific rules for capitalizing court names, judge titles, and references to terms of court.

sub_rules.title: Titles of Judges Before Names
sub_rules.description: Capitalize judicial and official titles when they precede a name.

sub_rules.title: Generic References
sub_rules.description: Lowercase judicial and official titles when used generically.

constitutional_amendments.capitalize: First Amendment, Second Amendment, Fourth Amendment
constitutional_amendments.rule: Capitalize specific amendments but not generic references

acts_and_statutes.capitalize: Civil Rights Act, Americans with Disabilities Act, Clean Water Act
acts_and_statutes.lowercase: the statute, a federal act, state legislation
acts_and_statutes.rule: Capitalize specific act names but not generic references

court_names.always_capitalize_court: The Court (referring to U.S. Supreme Court)
court_names.lowercase_other_courts: the lower courts, the appellate court, district court proceedings
court_names.capitalize_in_case_names: When referring to the court in a case name
court_names.rule: Capitalize 'Court' for U.S. Supreme Court, lowercase for others

judicial_titles.capitalize_before_name: Chief Justice Marshall, Justice Roberts, Judge Smith
judicial_titles.lowercase_generic: any justice may..., the chief justice held, a judge in that court
judicial_titles.capitalize_the_president: The President (when referring to specific office)
judicial_titles.lowercase_presidential: when the president acts, the president stated
judicial_titles.rule: Capitalize when preceding a name, lowercase when generic

terms_of_court.capitalize: Fall Term, Spring Term 2024, The October Term
terms_of_court.lowercase: the next term, during the court's term
terms_of_court.rule: Capitalize when naming a specific term, lowercase when generic

legal_documents.capitalize_specific: Brief for Petitioner, Motion in Limine, Plaintiff's Complaint
legal_documents.lowercase_generic: the brief, the motion, court documents
legal_documents.rule: Capitalize when referring to specific document, lowercase generically

formatting_requirements: Capitalize specific constitutional amendments
Capitalize specific acts and statute names
Capitalize 'Court' when referring to U.S. Supreme Court
Lowercase 'court' for other courts (unless official name)
Capitalize judicial titles before names
Lowercase judicial titles in generic use
Capitalize specific court document titles
Lowercase generic document references
Follow citation format rules for typeface
Maintain consistency throughout document

U.S. Supreme Court capitalized
Amendment reference should be capitalized

Some old or historical references may use different capitalization
Quoted material maintains original capitalization
Foreign or non-English material may have different rules
Some jurisdiction-specific rules may vary

12.rule_text: Cite statutes by their official or popular name (if commonly used) and the published source (code or session law) and year. Federal statutes: cite to the U.S. Code when available: Title U.S.C. § Section (Year). For state statutes: cite to the current code if available or the session law if not codified. Include supplements when applicable.

sub_rules.title: Basic Citation Forms
sub_rules.description: Standard format for federal and state statute citations with required elements.

sub_rules.title: Choosing the Proper Citation Form
sub_rules.description: Hierarchy of citation preference: official code, unofficial code, session laws.

sub_rules.description: Information about U.S.C., U.S.C.A., U.S.C.S., and state code editions.

sub_rules.title: Session Laws
sub_rules.description: Citation format for statutes not yet in the code.

sub_rules.description: Citation format for statutes found only online or in databases.

sub_rules.title: Special Citation Forms
sub_rules.description: Special formats for I.R.C., ordinances, rules of procedure, model codes, and restatements.

sub_rules.title: Short Forms for Statutes
sub_rules.description: Short form citations after full statute citation is provided.

state_statutes.third_choice: Session laws if not yet codified

federal_code.note: Year optional if citing current code

state_code.note: Year typically required for state codes

Include section symbol (§), not words
Include section number
Include year in parentheses (with exceptions)
Use official code when available
Cite range with double section symbol (§§)
Include supplement information when applicable
For state statutes, include state abbreviation and code name
No period after section symbol
Proper spacing in abbreviations (U.S.C. not USC)

15.rule_title: Books, Reports, and Other Nonperiodic Materials
15.rule_text: This rule covers how to cite books, treatises, reports, white papers, encyclopedias, dictionaries, and similar non-periodic sources. Include authors as names in full as given on the publication, titles italicized, edition if not first, and year of publication. Publisher information is generally not required for well-known legal publishers but is required for lesser-known works.

sub_rules.title: Author
sub_rules.description: Include the author's full name as it appears on the title page.

sub_rules.title: Editor or Translator
sub_rules.description: Include editor or translator information when relevant.

sub_rules.title: Title
sub_rules.description: Titles must be italicized with proper capitalization (title case).

sub_rules.title: Edition, Publisher, and Date
sub_rules.description: Include edition information (if not first), year of publication, and publisher when necessary.

sub_rules.title: Shorter Works in Collection
sub_rules.description: Citation format for essays, chapters, or articles within edited collections.

sub_rules.title: Prefaces, Forewords, Introductions
sub_rules.description: Special citation format for these supplementary materials.

sub_rules.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
sub_rules.description: Citation format for online books and electronic sources.

sub_rules.title: Short Citation Forms
sub_rules.description: Short form citations after full book citation is provided.

author_rules.rule: Use full names as given on title page

title_capitalization.lowercase: Articles (a, an, the), conjunctions (and, or, but), prepositions (in, on, at, by, from)
title_capitalization.exception: Always capitalize first and last words of title

edition_format.note: Edition comes before year in parentheses

For more than two authors: first author + et al.

punctuation.rule_text: The Bluebook contains comprehensive punctuation rules governing the proper use of commas, periods, semicolons, colons, parentheses, brackets, dashes, quotation marks, and other punctuation in legal citations and academic writing.

sub_rules.description: Citation clauses set off by commas; multiple authorities separated by commas or semicolons depending on context.
Citation sentences end with periods; no periods after section symbols or in degrees.
Semicolons separate signal groups and multiple authorities within parentheticals.
Court/year information in parentheses; explanatory parentheticals with proper content.
Square brackets for alterations in quotations and for nested parentheticals.
Colons separate titles from subtitles and introduce certain citations.
Em dashes for non-grammatical parentheticals; hyphens for ranges.
Proper quotation mark usage and three-dot ellipsis for omissions.
Proper spacing around all punctuation marks.

comma_rules.citation_clauses: Authorities supporting only part of sentence cited in clauses set off by commas
comma_rules.multiple_citations_same_signal: Separate with commas: See X, Y, and Z
comma_rules.compare_contrast: Separate with semicolons: Compare X, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), with Y, 410 U.S. 179 (1973)
comma_rules.parallel_citations: Separate with commas in periodical citations

period_rules.degrees: Include periods (J.D. not JD, Ph.D. not PhD)

semicolon_rules.same_signal_type: Separate multiple same-type signals with semicolons
semicolon_rules.parenthetical_citations: Separate multiple authorities in parenthetical with semicolons

parentheses_rules.court_year: Court abbreviation and year in parentheses
parentheses_rules.explanatory: Lowercase letter start unless first word is proper noun
parentheses_rules.no_nested: Use brackets instead of nested parentheses

bracket_rules.nested_parentheticals: Use brackets instead of parentheses: (text [inner text] text)
bracket_rules.translations: Use brackets for descriptive or translated titles

Multiple authorities same signal separated by commas
Multiple authorities compare/contrast separated by semicolons
Citation sentences end with period
No period after section symbol
Semicolons separate signal groups
Court/year in parentheses
No nested parentheses (use brackets)
Three dots only for ellipsis
Proper spacing around all punctuation

examples.text: (citing Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020); Doe v. Bolton, 410 U.S. 179 (1973))

No period after section symbol

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
1.1: Quoting and Citing Parentheticals

SLR always requires a quoting parenthetical when the quoted source is itself quoting another source. If the author has forgotten to include a quoting parenthetical, you are responsible for adding one yourself, which may involve locating and pulling the quoted source, citechecking it, and uploading it to Box. However, SLR never requires a citing parenthetical. If the author wants to include a citing parenthetical, they may do so, but you need not add one or ask the author to add one.

For quoting and citing parentheticals, you are responsible for citechecking the quoted or cited source just as if the author had cited it directly. Occasionally, checking the quoted source is impracticable because it is impossible to retrieve. If you add a quoting parenthetical but are unable to citecheck the quoted source, please be sure (1) to leave an [RCC] in the document and (2) to flag the issue for your SE.
rule_paragraphs: 1.1: Quoting and Citing Parentheticals

SLR always requires a quoting parenthetical when the quoted source is itself quoting another source. If the author has forgotten to include a quoting parenthetical, you are responsible for adding one yourself, which may involve locating and pulling the quoted source, citechecking it, and uploading it to Box. However, SLR never requires a citing parenthetical. If the author wants to include a citing parenthetical, they may do so, but you need not add one or ask the author to add one.

For quoting and citing parentheticals, you are responsible for citechecking the quoted or cited source just as if the author had cited it directly. Occasionally, checking the quoted source is impracticable because it is impossible to retrieve. If you add a quoting parenthetical but are unable to citecheck the quoted source, please be sure (1) to leave an [RCC] in the document and (2) to flag the issue for your SE.

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
16.5: Citing Abstracts

SLR does not cite abstracts. If the author has cited or quoted an abstract, either (1) change the pincite to wherever in the article the appropriate citation would be or (2) ask the author to do so. If the author has quoted a part of the abstract and the same language never appears later in the article, leave an AA note asking them to pick a different quotation. If the author cites the abstract because they are making a point about what the article is generally about, a citation to the introduction or conclusion will usually work as a substitute. If the citation to the introduction or conclusion addresses a point that goes beyond the general thrust of the article, you will need to find a new citation within the body of the article.
rule_paragraphs: 16.5: Citing Abstracts

SLR does not cite abstracts. If the author has cited or quoted an abstract, either (1) change the pincite to wherever in the article the appropriate citation would be or (2) ask the author to do so. If the author has quoted a part of the abstract and the same language never appears later in the article, leave an AA note asking them to pick a different quotation. If the author cites the abstract because they are making a point about what the article is generally about, a citation to the introduction or conclusion will usually work as a substitute. If the citation to the introduction or conclusion addresses a point that goes beyond the general thrust of the article, you will need to find a new citation within the body of the article.

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)
Pincite reference to page or page range

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
18.1: URLs

In all citations to internet sources, SLR includes an archival link. Contrary to BB 18.2.1(d), SLR never includes both an original and an archival link. SLR uses Perma.cc to archive internet sources. For more information about Perma.cc and its role in combating link rot, see https://perma.cc.

The MEs will convert all URLs to Perma.cc links between Round 2 and Galley Night. During Galley Night, you are responsible for checking the Perma.cc links to ensure that they are working. You do not need to alter them otherwise.

Where a (last visited) parenthetical would otherwise be required in a citation under BB 18.2.2(c)—that is, when there is no date provided on the website itself—it should be replaced with an (archived) parenthetical indicating the Perma.cc capture date. Examples :

If a webpage contains both the time and date of its original publication and the time and date it was updated (as is sometimes the case with news materials), include the latter in an (updated [date]) parenthetical in the same place you would put the date parenthetical otherwise (that is, before the URL). If the webpage is periodically updated and notes the date it was “last updated” or “last modified,” include that date in a (last updated [date]) parenthetical that replaces the archived date parenthetical (that is, after the URL), per BB 18.2.2(c). Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 18.1: URLs

In all citations to internet sources, SLR includes an archival link. Contrary to BB 18.2.1(d), SLR never includes both an original and an archival link. SLR uses Perma.cc to archive internet sources. For more information about Perma.cc and its role in combating link rot, see https://perma.cc.

The MEs will convert all URLs to Perma.cc links between Round 2 and Galley Night. During Galley Night, you are responsible for checking the Perma.cc links to ensure that they are working. You do not need to alter them otherwise.

Where a (last visited) parenthetical would otherwise be required in a citation under BB 18.2.2(c)—that is, when there is no date provided on the website itself—it should be replaced with an (archived) parenthetical indicating the Perma.cc capture date. Examples :

If a webpage contains both the time and date of its original publication and the time and date it was updated (as is sometimes the case with news materials), include the latter in an (updated [date]) parenthetical in the same place you would put the date parenthetical otherwise (that is, before the URL). If the webpage is periodically updated and notes the date it was “last updated” or “last modified,” include that date in a (last updated [date]) parenthetical that replaces the archived date parenthetical (that is, after the URL), per BB 18.2.2(c). Examples :

deviations_from_bluebook.text: In all citations to internet sources, SLR includes an archival link. Contrary to BB 18.2.1(d), SLR never includes both an original and an archival link.

correct_examples: Correct : Isaac W. Shapiro, A New Era for Bumble Bee Tuna , Applied Ichthyology Q. (June 30, 2023, 3:04 AM PDT), https://perma.cc/NL8B-AFTG (discussing beekeeping’s lessons for the aquaculture industry).
Correct : Conrad Sproul, A Guide to Having Your Online Submission Published , Phat Chance Blog , https://perma.cc/5BJC-B6XV (archived July 7, 2020).
Correct : Andrew J. Park, Caffeination at SLS: What to Do When the Free Coffee Machine is Broken , Stan. Pub. Prot. Cmty. Comm’n (updated Aug. 20, 2023), https://perma.cc/65KH-59EN.
Correct : Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, Outlook Notifications Haunt Our Dreams , Exec. Ed. Dig. , https://perma.cc/AX3N-AXAJ (last updated Aug. 22, 2023).

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
18.4: Dates and Times

Include all of the date/time information provided by the website, formatted by analogy with the following example: (Feb. 1, 2004, 3:56:24 PM CST). If the website does not provide all of the information, include whatever information is available. Note that time zones such as PST, PDT, and PT are all valid, and all mean different things; thus, do not “correct” time zones except to remove periods. Example :

If the webpage provides a time in 24-hour format, translate the time into AM/PM format. Example :

If the webpage does not provide any date/time information, the Managing Editors will include the date the Perma.cc record was created in a parenthetical after the URL. SLR never uses “last visited” parentheticals. When you encounter a source without any date/time information, please insert an “archived” parenthetical but leave the date blank. Example :

SLR never uses “last visited” parentheticals. When you encounter a source without any date/time information, please insert an “archived” parenthetical but leave the date blank. Example :

correct_examples: Correct : Jennifer L. Portis, Multimedia? More Like Multi-meme-dia , NBC News (Jan. 7, 2022, 7:03:07 PM PST), https://perma.cc/TR8M-QQR8 (advocating for creation of a “Meme-ber Editor” board position).

Correct : Christopher Huberty, They Both Have a Salesforce Tower: Why There Are No Discernible Differences Between Indianapolis and San Francisco , Architectural Dig. (May 10, 2022, 11:40 PM EDT), https://perma.cc/VM8A-QC5P.
Correct : Julia Gokhberg, Please Come to the Symposium , Please , https://perma.cc/ZHR5-5RP4 (archived Sept. 28, 2023).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Jennifer L. Portis, Multimedia? More Like Multi-meme-dia , NBC News (Jan. 7, 2022, 7:03 PM P.S.T.), https://perma.cc/TR8M-QQR8 (advocating for creation of a “Meme-ber Editor” board position).

Incorrect : Christopher Huberty, They Both Have a Salesforce Tower: Why There Are No Discernible Differences Between Indianapolis and San Francisco , Architectural Dig. (May 10, 2022, 23:40 EDT), https://perma.cc/VM8A-QC5P.

slr_specific_rules.section_title: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization
slr_specific_rules.rule_summary: 1.13: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization
slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
1.13: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization

SLR uses (emphasis omitted) when the cited source uses formatting to emphasize a word or phrase and the author wants to omit that emphasis. If the cited source contains multiple separate emphases and the author omits all of them, simply use (emphasis omitted), not (emphases omitted). Example :

SLR allows (capitalization altered) in lieu of brackets to indicate altered capitalization in a direct quotation when doing so would significantly improve readability. Drop an [SE:] comment if you think (capitalization altered) might be appropriate but the author has not yet suggested it. Examples :

Do not indicate changes to the typography or layout of quoted material that do not serve to remove emphasis. See RB 5.4; cf. CMOS 13.8. SLR does not use (formatting altered), (italics omitted), or (bolding omitted). If the typographical change does remove substantive emphasis, use (emphasis omitted). Example :
rule_paragraphs: 1.13: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization

SLR uses (emphasis omitted) when the cited source uses formatting to emphasize a word or phrase and the author wants to omit that emphasis. If the cited source contains multiple separate emphases and the author omits all of them, simply use (emphasis omitted), not (emphases omitted). Example :

SLR allows (capitalization altered) in lieu of brackets to indicate altered capitalization in a direct quotation when doing so would significantly improve readability. Drop an [SE:] comment if you think (capitalization altered) might be appropriate but the author has not yet suggested it. Examples :

Do not indicate changes to the typography or layout of quoted material that do not serve to remove emphasis. See RB 5.4; cf. CMOS 13.8. SLR does not use (formatting altered), (italics omitted), or (bolding omitted). If the typographical change does remove substantive emphasis, use (emphasis omitted). Example :
correct_examples: Original text :     One arises from a desertion of duty, and the other dessert fails to rise.
Citation : Garrett M. Wen, Musings on Torts and Tortes , 75 Stan. L. Rev. 104, 128-29 (2023) ("One arises from a desertion of duty, and the other dessert fails to rise." (emphasis omitted)).
Original text :   No Additional Process Is Due.

Correct : Brief of Stanford University at 24, Leland Stanford Junior Univ. v. Stanford L. Rev., 904 F.3d 126 (9th Cir. 2020) (No. 18-837), 2020 LEXIS App. 953154, at *15 (arguing that "no additional process is due" (capitalization altered)).

Also correct : Brief of Stanford University at 24, Leland Stanford Junior Univ. v. Stanford L. Rev., 904 F.3d 126 (9th Cir. 2020) (No. 18-837), 2020 LEXIS App. 953154, at *15 (arguing that "[n]o [a]dditional [p]rocess [i]s [d]ue" [SE: Consider (capitalization altered).] ).
Original text : Look, we can't all release two new albums during quarantine. If we could, we would all be the greatest songwriters of our generation.
Correct : Madison A. Burson, We'll Never Find Another Like Taylor: The Greatest Songwriter of Our Generation 41 (2024) (observing that "we can't all release two new albums during quarantine").

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
22.4: Quotation Marks and Apostrophes

SLR exclusively uses smart/curly quotes (for example, “and” or “a husky’s howl”) to designate quoted material; SLR never uses straight quotes or apostrophes (for example, "and" or "a husky's howl").

Use caution when applying smart/curly quotes to case names beginning with “Mc” or “Mac.” The apostrophe in these case names is a “turned comma,” and should face in the opposite direction of what Word’s smart quotes feature wants. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 22.4: Quotation Marks and Apostrophes
SLR exclusively uses smart/curly quotes (for example, “and” or “a husky’s howl”) to designate quoted material; SLR never uses straight quotes or apostrophes (for example, "and" or "a husky's howl").

Use caution when applying smart/curly quotes to case names beginning with “Mc” or “Mac.” The apostrophe in these case names is a “turned comma,” and should face in the opposite direction of what Word’s smart quotes feature wants. Example :
correct_examples: Correct : Johnson v. M‘Intosh, 21 U.S. (7 Wheat.) 543 (1823).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Johnson v. M’Intosh, 21 U.S. (7 Wheat.) 543 (1823).

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
22.5: Commas

SLR defers to the author’s preference regarding commas unless the use violates one of the three rules laid out below or is clearly grammatically incorrect.

Serial (Oxford) comma : SLR uses a comma after the penultimate item in a series. CMOS 6.19; see also CMOS 6.60; cf. O’Connor v. Oakhurst Dairy, 851 F.3d 69, 70 (1st Cir. 2017) (“For want of a comma, we have this case.”). But see Vampire Weekend, Oxford Comma , on Vampire Weekend (XL Recordings 2008). Example :

Initial conjunctions : For the purposes of readability and clarity, commas should not be used to set off initial conjunctions of three or fewer letters (“so,” “and,” “but,” and “yet”). If an initial conjunction of three or fewer letters is followed by a parenthetical phrase that is itself normally set off by commas, defer to the author’s preference (but flag for your SE so that they can ensure consistency throughout). Examples :

“That” and dependent clauses: Omit a comma after “that” when it introduces a dependent clause. Cf. CMOS 6.26.

Example :
rule_paragraphs: 22.5: Commas
SLR defers to the author’s preference regarding commas unless the use violates one of the three rules laid out below or is clearly grammatically incorrect.

Serial (Oxford) comma : SLR uses a comma after the penultimate item in a series. CMOS 6.19; see also CMOS 6.60; cf. O’Connor v. Oakhurst Dairy, 851 F.3d 69, 70 (1st Cir. 2017) (“For want of a comma, we have this case.”). But see Vampire Weekend, Oxford Comma , on Vampire Weekend (XL Recordings 2008). Example :

Initial conjunctions : For the purposes of readability and clarity, commas should not be used to set off initial conjunctions of three or fewer letters (“so,” “and,” “but,” and “yet”). If an initial conjunction of three or fewer letters is followed by a parenthetical phrase that is itself normally set off by commas, defer to the author’s preference (but flag for your SE so that they can ensure consistency throughout). Examples :
“That” and dependent clauses: Omit a comma after “that” when it introduces a dependent clause. Cf. CMOS 6.26.
Example :
correct_examples: Correct : I’d like to thank my parents, Britney Spears, and Nelson Mandela.
Correct : And don’t call me Shirley.
Correct : But, on the other hand, I can’t stop you.
Also correct : But on the other hand, I can’t stop you.
Correct : The court held that although hot dogs could be considered sandwiches, a hot dog does not fall within the plain (or “cocktail party”) meaning of “sandwich.”
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : I’d like to thank my parents, Britney Spears and Nelson Mandela.
Incorrect : And, don’t call me Shirley.
Incorrect : The court held that, although hot dogs could be considered sandwiches, a hot dog does not fall within the plain (or “cocktail party”) meaning of “sandwich.”

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
22.6: Hyphens and Dashes

SLR uses hyphens (that is, “-”) and em dashes (that is, “—”) in accordance with the rules and examples of The

Bluebook and CMOS . Note, however, that unlike The Bluebook and CMOS , SLR does not use en dashes (that is, “–”). Where en dashes are suggested by The Bluebook or CMOS , hyphens are the appropriate substitute (including in quotations, see RB 5.4).

Hyphens are generally used in compound words and names and in word division; they also are used to separate numbers and indicate number ranges. But see BB 3.2(d). Em dashes are generally used to set off an amplifying or explanatory element in a sentence (for example, “It was a revival of the most potent image in modern democracy—the revolutionary idea.”).

There are no spaces before or after em dashes or hyphens. Examples :

Remove any spaces around em dashes or hyphens in quoted material without comment. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 22.6: Hyphens and Dashes
SLR uses hyphens (that is, “-”) and em dashes (that is, “—”) in accordance with the rules and examples of The

Bluebook and CMOS . Note, however, that unlike The Bluebook and CMOS , SLR does not use en dashes (that is, “–”). Where en dashes are suggested by The Bluebook or CMOS , hyphens are the appropriate substitute (including in quotations, see RB 5.4).

Hyphens are generally used in compound words and names and in word division; they also are used to separate numbers and indicate number ranges. But see BB 3.2(d). Em dashes are generally used to set off an amplifying or explanatory element in a sentence (for example, “It was a revival of the most potent image in modern democracy—the revolutionary idea.”).
There are no spaces before or after em dashes or hyphens. Examples :
Remove any spaces around em dashes or hyphens in quoted material without comment. See RB 5.4.

deviations_from_bluebook.text: Note, however, that unlike The Bluebook and CMOS , SLR does not use en dashes (that is, “–”). Where en dashes are suggested by The Bluebook or CMOS , hyphens are the appropriate substitute (including in quotations, see RB 5.4).

correct_examples: Correct : Most law students—but not all—study for exams.
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Some law students — but not those at Stanford — sit in the sun all day.

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
22.7: The One-Space Rule

SLR always uses only one space after periods, colons, or semicolons. This includes quoted material: Where such material uses two spaces, replace with one space and do not indicate it as an alteration. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 22.7: The One-Space Rule

SLR always uses only one space after periods, colons, or semicolons. This includes quoted material: Where such material uses two spaces, replace with one space and do not indicate it as an alteration. See RB 5.4.

regex_patterns.description: Single space after period (correct SLR style)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
1.14: Added Alterations and Retained Emphasis

SLR never uses (alteration added) or (emphasis in original) parentheticals. No indication is necessary to show that an alteration to quoted text is added or that emphasis in quoted text is present in the original.
rule_paragraphs: 1.14: Added Alterations and Retained Emphasis

SLR never uses (alteration added) or (emphasis in original) parentheticals. No indication is necessary to show that an alteration to quoted text is added or that emphasis in quoted text is present in the original.

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
2.1: Underlined Type

SLR does not use underlined type. Use italics instead—including in quotations. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 2.1: Underlined Type
SLR does not use underlined type. Use italics instead—including in quotations. See RB 5.4.

regex_patterns.description: Underlined text (SLR does not use underlines)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
3.4: Internal Cross-References

SLR uses the terms " supra " and " infra " for internal cross-references, see BB 3.5, when cited in footnotes. If such terms are used in the text or in textual sentences in footnotes (including in textual stringcites), they should be replaced with "above" and "below." Supra and infra should always precede the pincite. "Above" and "below" should follow it. Examples :

Please do not add dynamic cross-references to Parts or Subparts in Word; however, if the author has done so, you may leave them in place.

A cross-reference to other footnotes can take several forms; see BB 3.5 for examples. To summarize:
rule_paragraphs: 3.4: Internal Cross-References

SLR uses the terms " supra " and " infra " for internal cross-references, see BB 3.5, when cited in footnotes. If such terms are used in the text or in textual sentences in footnotes (including in textual stringcites), they should be replaced with "above" and "below." Supra and infra should always precede the pincite. "Above" and "below" should follow it. Examples :
Please do not add dynamic cross-references to Parts or Subparts in Word; however, if the author has done so, you may leave them in place.
A cross-reference to other footnotes can take several forms; see BB 3.5 for examples. To summarize:
correct_examples: As explained above, the Court's arbitration jurisprudence has become increasingly hostile to state law measures. 171 But as discussed in Part III.B.2 below, early cases gave space for state regulation. 172

See supra notes 50-51 and accompanying text. It took decades for the Court to breathe life into the FAA. For academic commentary on this transition, see Part IV.A below. See also infra Part IV.B.2 (detailing lower courts' efforts to comply).
structured_lists: See supra notes 50-51 and accompanying text.
It took decades for the Court to breathe life into the FAA. For academic commentary on this transition, see Part IV.A below. See also infra Part IV.B.2 (detailing lower courts' efforts to comply).
Citing substantive footnote[s] and corresponding body text.
Referring mainly to body text, and the footnote[s] are used simply to identify the location;
or referring to body text, and the footnote[s] contain only citations and not additional substantive text.
Citing a substantive discussion wholly contained within footnote[s].
Citing a specific individual source that was first cited in note x .
Use this form even if the cross-referenced footnote contains only a single citation and no other text.
When referring to multiple citations in the cross-referenced footnote(s) but not to substantive text.

regex_patterns.description: Pincite reference to page or page range
Supra with page reference (no note number)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
3.5: Inserting Cross-References

SLR uses automatic cross-references for all supra and infra citations during the editing process to ensure accuracy while we add or rearrange footnotes. When an author cites a source using a supra form, see BB 4.2(a), or refers to another footnote within the article (for example, " see infra note 44 and accompanying text"), the footnote number should be provided using an automatic cross-reference rather than plain text. If the document already contains a cross-reference, make sure it is updated and still points to the correct footnote (to update dynamic cross-references, see the keyboard shortcuts table at the end of this document). If a cross-reference cannot be properly linked to the footnote to which it refers, leave an [RCC] .
rule_paragraphs: 3.5: Inserting Cross-References

SLR uses automatic cross-references for all supra and infra citations during the editing process to ensure accuracy while we add or rearrange footnotes. When an author cites a source using a supra form, see BB 4.2(a), or refers to another footnote within the article (for example, " see infra note 44 and accompanying text"), the footnote number should be provided using an automatic cross-reference rather than plain text. If the document already contains a cross-reference, make sure it is updated and still points to the correct footnote (to update dynamic cross-references, see the keyboard shortcuts table at the end of this document). If a cross-reference cannot be properly linked to the footnote to which it refers, leave an [RCC] .

regex_patterns.description: Supra with page reference (no note number)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
3.6: Pincites

SLR requires pincites in citations. There are two exceptions:
rule_paragraphs: 3.6: Pincites
SLR requires pincites in citations. There are two exceptions:
structured_lists: When the footnote is merely an identifying footnote under RB 1.2, or
when it is used in a See generally citation and you leave a comment in the citecheck spreadsheet indicating why a pincite would not be helpful or necessary in that instance.

regex_patterns.description: Pincite reference to page or page range

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
3.7: Et seq.

SLR does not use et seq. Instead, specify the full range of sections or subdivisions to which the author is referring. If you have any doubts, leave an [AA:] note asking the author to specify the applicable sections.
rule_paragraphs: 3.7: Et seq.

SLR does not use et seq. Instead, specify the full range of sections or subdivisions to which the author is referring. If you have any doubts, leave an [AA:] note asking the author to specify the applicable sections.

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
4.1: Using Id.

Where appropriate, SLR requires the use of id. unless it would be potentially ambiguous. Id. is appropriate in exactly three cases: (1) as the first citation in a footnote, if and only if the preceding footnote cites only to that same, single source (not including quoting or citing parentheticals); (2) as the first or only citation in a citation clause or sentence later in a footnote, if and only if the previous citation (or stringcite) cites only that same, single source (again, not including parentheticals); and (3) within a stringcite, when citing the immediately preceding source in that same stringcite. Examples :

L. Rev. 25, 38 (2002); see also id. at 42 (allowed by case 3). Some authors blame a lack of infrastructural investment for today's problems. See Stanford, supra , at 45 (not id. -eligible because the preceding citation sentence contains multiple sources). But see id. at 48 (allowed by case 2).
rule_paragraphs: 4.1: Using Id.

Where appropriate, SLR requires the use of id. unless it would be potentially ambiguous. Id. is appropriate in exactly three cases: (1) as the first citation in a footnote, if and only if the preceding footnote cites only to that same, single source (not including quoting or citing parentheticals); (2) as the first or only citation in a citation clause or sentence later in a footnote, if and only if the previous citation (or stringcite) cites only that same, single source (again, not including parentheticals); and (3) within a stringcite, when citing the immediately preceding source in that same stringcite. Examples :

L. Rev. 25, 38 (2002); see also id. at 42 (allowed by case 3). Some authors blame a lack of infrastructural investment for today's problems. See Stanford, supra , at 45 (not id. -eligible because the preceding citation sentence contains multiple sources). But see id. at 48 (allowed by case 2).
correct_examples: John Harvard, It Only Takes a Few Books , 103 Harv. L. Rev. 354, 357 (1991); Leland Stanford, More Railroads , 55 Stan. L. Rev. 25, 38 (2002); see also id. at 42 (allowed by case 3). Some authors blame a lack of infrastructural investment for today's problems. See Stanford, supra , at 45 (not id. -eligible because the preceding citation sentence contains multiple sources). But see id. at 48 (allowed by case 2). Cf., e.g. , Stanford, supra note 495, at 45 (not id. -eligible because the preceding footnote contains multiple sources). See id. at 50 (allowed by case 1); see also Harvard, supra note 495, at 357.
structured_lists: John Harvard, It Only Takes a Few Books , 103 Harv. L. Rev. 354, 357 (1991); Leland Stanford, More Railroads , 55 Stan. L. Rev. 25, 38 (2002); see also id. at 42 (allowed by case 3). Some authors blame a lack of infrastructural investment for today's problems. See Stanford, supra , at 45 (not id. -eligible because the preceding citation sentence contains multiple sources). But see id. at 48 (allowed by case 2).
Cf., e.g. , Stanford, supra note 495, at 45 (not id. -eligible because the preceding footnote contains multiple sources).
See id. at 50 (allowed by case 1); see also Harvard, supra note 495, at 357.

Supra with page reference (no note number)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
6.1: Abbreviating Professional Degrees

Contrary to CMOS 10.21, SLR does not omit periods in educational degrees. Use "J.D." instead of "JD" and "Ph.D." over "PhD" (and so on). Note that we would never include an author's degree—periods or not—in a citation. See BB 15.1.
rule_paragraphs: 6.1: Abbreviating Professional Degrees

Contrary to CMOS 10.21, SLR does not omit periods in educational degrees. Use "J.D." instead of "JD" and "Ph.D." over "PhD" (and so on). Note that we would never include an author's degree—periods or not—in a citation. See BB 15.1.

deviations_from_bluebook.text: Contrary to CMOS 10.21, SLR does not omit periods in educational degrees. Use "J.D." instead of "JD" and "Ph.D." over "PhD" (and so on).

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
10.4: Procedural Phrases in Case Names

SLR always includes " ex rel. " when the reporter links the named party to another party with a phrase starting with "as" or "on behalf of" or something similar. See BB 10.2.1(b). Beware that the case caption at the top of the reporter page often omits " ex rel. " even in cases where SLR would include it. When in doubt, include the procedural phrase and leave a comment for your SE.
rule_paragraphs: 10.4: Procedural Phrases in Case Names

SLR always includes " ex rel. " when the reporter links the named party to another party with a phrase starting with "as" or "on behalf of" or something similar. See BB 10.2.1(b). Beware that the case caption at the top of the reporter page often omits " ex rel. " even in cases where SLR would include it. When in doubt, include the procedural phrase and leave a comment for your SE.

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
10.11: Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases

To clarify BB 10.8.1, SLR has established the following order of preference for cases that are not to be published in reporters:

SLR does not cite services. See BB 19. When pulling cases, be careful about whether you are pulling from a reporter or a service. Westlaw and Lexis carry some services and do not always clearly distinguish them from reporters. For a partial list of services, see BB Table T15.
rule_paragraphs: 10.11: Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases
To clarify BB 10.8.1, SLR has established the following order of preference for cases that are not to be published in reporters:

SLR does not cite services. See BB 19. When pulling cases, be careful about whether you are pulling from a reporter or a service. Westlaw and Lexis carry some services and do not always clearly distinguish them from reporters. For a partial list of services, see BB Table T15.

deviations_from_bluebook.text: SLR does not cite services. See BB 19.

structured_lists: Electronic databases : Westlaw, Lexis, and Bloomberg, in that order. See BB 10.8.1(a). Slip opinions : If available online. See BB 10.8.1(b).

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
10.12: Docket Numbers in Federal Cases

When citing a federal docket number, write the number as it appears in the source and do not reorder the elements (namely the year, case type, and case number) with respect to each other. To clarify BB 10.8.1(a), SLR always omits any initial digit that precedes a colon and any judge's initials that follow the essential docket information. Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 10.12: Docket Numbers in Federal Cases

When citing a federal docket number, write the number as it appears in the source and do not reorder the elements (namely the year, case type, and case number) with respect to each other. To clarify BB 10.8.1(a), SLR always omits any initial digit that precedes a colon and any judge's initials that follow the essential docket information. Examples :
correct_examples: Original : No. 2:12-cr-02323-AB
Correct : No. 12-cr-02323
Original : No. 99-839-cv (JPO) (EMG)
Correct : No. 99-839-cv

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)
Docket number with initial digit before colon (remove per SLR)
Docket number, possibly with judge initials (remove initials per SLR)

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
10.15: Public Domain

SLR does not use public domain citation formats. Any BB rule requiring a public domain citation (for example, BB Table T1.3 specifications for Vermont court citations) should not be observed.
rule_paragraphs: 10.15: Public Domain
SLR does not use public domain citation formats. Any BB rule requiring a public domain citation (for example, BB Table T1.3 specifications for Vermont court citations) should not be observed.

deviations_from_bluebook.text: SLR does not use public domain citation formats. Any BB rule requiring a public domain citation (for example, BB Table T1.3 specifications for Vermont court citations) should not be observed.

slr_specific_rules.section_title: Dates for the United States Code
slr_specific_rules.rule_summary: 12.1: Dates for the United States Code
slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
12.1: Dates for the United States Code

Cite the latest edition of the United States Code unless the context specifically demands otherwise (for example, in a historical discussion). If you are unsure which edition to cite, ask your SE.

To clarify BB 12.3.2, SLR never includes a date in a citation to the latest edition of the Code. However, a citation to a historical version of the Code should contain the year in parentheses. Examples :

To find the latest edition of the Code or a historical edition from 1994 or later, use govinfo. Browse the Code at https://www.govinfo.gov/app/collection/uscode or search the Code by citation elements at https://www.govinfo.gov/#citation . To find a historical edition of the Code from before 1994, use HeinOnline.

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
12.3: Short Forms for Statutes

To clarify BB 12.10(b), the short form for statutes can be used (subject to the five-footnote rule, see BB 10.9(a)) for citations to any section within the same title of the code, but the long form must be repeated for citations to different titles. Examples :

However, SLR does not use a short form version (other than id. ) that omits the title number or statute name.

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
12.8: Codification Information for Session Laws

SLR always includes codification information when citing statutes as session laws. See BB 12.4(f). If only certain sections of the session law are cited, give the codification information for those sections. If the entire session law is cited, give the codification information for the entire act. To find codification information, use the Office of the Law Revision Counsel (OLRC) tables here , here , and here . More detailed instructions for finding codification information are included at the end of this document. Please consult the MEs with questions on how to use or navigate these tables. A session law is "codified as amended" if any codified provision was subsequently updated or revised. Otherwise, it is simply "codified." Examples :

The same conventions apply for citations to state session laws or to material codified in the Code of Federal Regulations . Examples :

IoT Cybersecurity Improvement Act of 2020, Pub. L. No. 116-207, § 4, 134 Stat. 1001, 1002-03 (codified at 15 U.S.C. § 278g-3b).

slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
15.2: Subtitles

SLR always includes subtitles. This applies to all types of sources and deviates from the portion of BB 15.3 that encourages the omission of subtitles.

A title and subtitle must be separated by punctuation. If the source contains no such punctuation on its title page (that is, if the title and subtitle are distinguished solely by typography), separate them with a colon. See CMOS 14.89. Otherwise, separate the title and subtitle with the same punctuation used in the source, whether a colon, dash, question mark, exclamation mark, period, other character, or combination of such marks. See CMOS 14.96. If the source already contains a punctuation mark, do not add another.

If a source has multiple subtitles, include only the first subtitle; or, if the multiple subtitles are of the same degree of importance and no specific punctuation is provided in the source, keep them and separate them with a semicolon. See CMOS 8.164, 14.90. Example :

If a source’s principal subtitle is set off with an em dash, any sub-subtitle should be set off with a colon, not a semicolon, if no specific punctuation is provided in the source. Example :

If a subtitle is unwieldy, leave a comment for your SE.

slr_specific_rules.rule_summary: 16.3: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles
slr_specific_rules.full_rule_text:
16.3: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles

If an online version of a newspaper or magazine is available, SLR uses an internet citation under BB 18.2.2 (as amended by RB 18 below), not a citation to the print copy of the newspaper or magazine. If for some reason it appears that a print copy is preferable, please flag the issue for your SE.

To clarify, the effect of this rule is that BB 16.6 is rarely used for newspapers and BB 16.5 is generally used only for journals, except for older sources that lack an online equivalent.
rule_paragraphs: 16.3: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles

If an online version of a newspaper or magazine is available, SLR uses an internet citation under BB 18.2.2 (as amended by RB 18 below), not a citation to the print copy of the newspaper or magazine. If for some reason it appears that a print copy is preferable, please flag the issue for your SE.
To clarify, the effect of this rule is that BB 16.6 is rarely used for newspapers and BB 16.5 is generally used only for journals, except for older sources that lack an online equivalent.

bluebook_deviations.rule_summary: The Redbook is the guide that Stanford Law Review ( SLR ) uses to clarify and expand on the conventions in The Bluebook . The Redbook is not comprehensive; it merely supplements—and sometimes overrules— The Bluebook . These rules allow SLR to maintain the same style conventions across everything it publishes, including both print and online pieces.
bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
The Redbook is the guide that Stanford Law Review ( SLR ) uses to clarify and expand on the conventions in The Bluebook . The Redbook is not comprehensive; it merely supplements—and sometimes overrules— The Bluebook . These rules allow SLR to maintain the same style conventions across everything it publishes, including both print and online pieces.

Edited by Volume 78 Managing Editors

Hierarchy of Rules

The following represents the hierarchy of sources for stylistic and editing rules that SLR follows:

These sources must be used in conjunction with one another. Each source on the list takes precedence over the sources below it.

Instances where The Redbook contradicts The Bluebook or The Chicago Manual of Style are marked in red font throughout this document. All other rules are clarifications but still supersede.

Comments and Annotations

Where you direct edits into the document on behalf of SLR , you will occasionally feel the desire to explain a particularly ambiguous cite or convention, seek clarification from an author, or flag a formatting issue. Where you do need to leave a comment in the document, do not use Microsoft Word's comment function . "Comments" for SLR purposes are in-line notations made directly into the text of the document:

*Not a real case.

It is important to place all comments directly next to the relevant text without any spaces between the comment and the text.

In practice : Anything you introduce into the document—including a comment directed at an SE or ME—is likely to find its way back to the author, even if by mistake. Therefore, all comments should be tactful. In case of doubt, leave your comment solely in the citecheck spreadsheet.

Please direct each comment to the appropriate person using annotation symbols to introduce the text:

AA (Author Attention)

Use [AA:] comments to request that the author (1) provide an additional citation; (2) provide 
        or confirm a pincite; or (3) rewrite an incomprehensible passage. Please phrase your comments as requests and provide suggestions 
        for improvement. Comments about the substantive correctness of a citation should go in the citecheck spreadsheet; the SE will turn 
        them into inline [AA:] comments if she decides it is necessary for the author to address the issue.

SE (Senior Editor)

Use [SE:] notations to alert your Senior Editor to minor problems that are better resolved by SLR staff rather than by the author and are more easily described inline than in the citecheck spreadsheet. Be sure to 
        (1) describe the nature of the problem; (2) suggest a solution; and, if it’s an editing concern, (3) direct the SE’s attention 
        to any portion of The Bluebook , The Redbook , or CMOS that may be relevant in resolving the issue. Do 
        not use [SE:] comments to raise substantive citechecking problems; those comments should be 
        left in the citecheck spreadsheet. If you think future editors would benefit from seeing the problem and its resolution, use the 
        citecheck spreadsheet. If the problem is serious or pervasive, please email your SE right away in addition to leaving an [SE:] comment or citecheck spreadsheet note.

ME (Managing Editor)

Use [ME:] notations to alert the Managing Editors about technical changes that need to be made to 
        the formatting of the article (for example, headers, footnote numbering, pagination, or anything that requires manual intervention 
        in Word). Do not adjust the formatting of the piece on your own, and never add or delete a footnote.

RCC (Re-Citecheck)

Use [RCC] notations to flag sources that could not be fully citechecked. Before adding an [RCC] comment, make a good-faith effort to find the source. This good-faith effort may include 
      (1) pulling, scanning, and uploading the source yourself (or submitting a Pull-and-Scan request form asking the Library to 
      do so); (2) requesting an interlibrary loan (ILL) through Crown Library (which you can find more information about in the 
      Member Editor Handbook); (3) asking the Executive Editors and Managing Editors to help you find a source; and (4) reaching 
      out to your SE to ask whether the author has a copy of the source. Do not reach out to the author directly by email unless 
      instructed to do so by your SE or someone on the Board. [RCC] notations should be used very 
      rarely, and once an [RCC] is added, you remain responsible for following up until the source 
      is properly located and citechecked.

The Redbook is not comprehensive; it merely supplements—and sometimes overrules— The Bluebook . These rules allow SLR to maintain the same style conventions across everything it publishes, including both print and online pieces.

      is properly located and citechecked.

correct_examples: The sky is blue. Doe v. Smith , 123 U.S. 1, 8 (1926). [SE: The source says that the sky is azure.]
The sky is blue. Doe v. Smith , 123 U.S. 1, 8 (1926) # [SE:  . . . .] (# means space. Do not do this).

18.9: Movies

Contrary to BB 18.6, SLR includes the director(s) rather than the production company in citations to films. bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
22.1: Spelling

Always use Merriam-Webster ’s preferred spelling. Do not simply trust your Microsoft Word dictionary, which in many cases does not conform to Merriam-Webster . For more obscure words, look to the Oxford English Dictionary for guidance—but if the word does not appear in Merriam-Webster , leave a comment for your SE.

SLR prefers the U.S. spelling of words over foreign spellings: Use “honor” instead of “honour” and “toward” instead of “towards.” However, these preferences apply only to the author’s own words, not to quoted material, which should be left as originally written without [sic]. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 22.1: Spelling

For more obscure words, look to the Oxford English Dictionary for guidance—but if the word does not appear in Merriam-Webster , leave a comment for your SE.

SLR prefers the U.S. spelling of words over foreign spellings: Use “honor” instead of “honour” and “toward” instead of “towards.” However, these preferences apply only to the author’s own words, not to quoted material, which should be left as originally written without [sic]. See RB 5.4.

22.3: Hyphenation

Look to CMOS ’s table ( https://perma.cc/MF36-LYUT ) and Merriam-Webster for questions about hyphenation. When editing a piece, leave a comment for your SE any time you (i) notice inconsistent hyphenation within the piece or (ii) think a term or phrase should be hyphenated.

When discussing hyphenation matters, the following taxonomy is helpful for consistency:

22.10: Capital Letter After a Colon

SLR follows a straightforward rule to determine whether to capitalize the first word after a colon: Capitalize if the word is a proper noun or the start of a complete sentence. Contra CMOS 6.63. Examples :

bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
10.6: Parallel Citations for Court Filings

When citing documents under BB 10.8.3, include a parallel citation to an electronic database (Westlaw, Lexis, or Bloomberg, in that order of preference) whenever possible. If you cannot locate the document on an electronic database, leave a comment for your SE.

Contrary to BB 10.8.3, pincites to an electronic database should be included only if either (1) the pagination of the format-preserving version differs from the star pagination or (2) the format-preserving version is unavailable. Examples :

Thus, to citecheck a court filing correctly, you must pull and review both the original PDF of the filing and the electronic database version. If a decision has been rendered on the filing (as in all three examples above), you must also pull the format-preserving version of the decision.
rule_paragraphs: 10.6: Parallel Citations for Court Filings

When citing documents under BB 10.8.3, include a parallel citation to an electronic database (Westlaw, Lexis, or Bloomberg, in that order of preference) whenever possible. If you cannot locate the document on an electronic database, leave a comment for your SE.

Contrary to BB 10.8.3, pincites to an electronic database should be included only if either (1) the pagination of the format-preserving version differs from the star pagination or (2) the format-preserving version is unavailable. Examples :

Thus, to citecheck a court filing correctly, you must pull and review both the original PDF of the filing and the electronic database version. If a decision has been rendered on the filing (as in all three examples above), you must also pull the format-preserving version of the decision.

Correct : Reply Brief for the Petitioner, INS v. Cardoza-Fonseca, 480 U.S. 421 (1987) (No. 85-782), 1986 WL 727544, at *1.

14.1: Federal Register Dates

Contrary to the implication of BB 14.2(a), use the date that appears at the top of the page of the Federal Register rather than the date on which a rule was promulgated or a notice announced.
rule_paragraphs: 14.1: Federal Register Dates

bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
15.1: Et al.

For sources of all types except amicus briefs, see RB 10.5, the first citation should include the full names of all authors, editors, and translators instead of being abbreviated with “et al.” Contra BB 15.1(b), 15.2(a), (b). If the list seems unwieldy, leave a comment for your SE.

For a source with three or more authors, subsequent citations that use a supra form should include only the first author’s last name, followed by “et al.”
rule_paragraphs: 15.1: Et al.

For sources of all types except amicus briefs, see RB 10.5, the first citation should include the full names of all authors, editors, and translators instead of being abbreviated with “et al.” Contra BB 15.1(b), 15.2(a), (b). If the list seems unwieldy, leave a comment for your SE.
For a source with three or more authors, subsequent citations that use a supra form should include only the first author’s last name, followed by “et al.”

If the list seems unwieldy, leave a comment for your SE.

bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
15.4: Online Treatises

When citing regularly updated treatises, SLR prefers to cite to the authoritative electronic database instead of the print edition even where the database version does not preserve the print formatting. When citing an electronic database version of a treatise, include the electronic publisher name in the date parenthetical as you would with a state statute. Examples :

The works in the first two examples above have a special citation form provided by BB 15.8(a), and they cannot be cited using supra or hereinafter. If such a source has been cited in any form within the previous five footnotes, see RB 10.9, omit the publisher-and-date parenthetical but do not otherwise use a short form.

Please note that there may be circumstances when you need to cite an older version of a treatise. In such situations, you should cite to a print edition. Notify your SE if you are unsure which edition should be cited.
rule_paragraphs: 15.4: Online Treatises

When citing regularly updated treatises, SLR prefers to cite to the authoritative electronic database instead of the print edition even where the database version does not preserve the print formatting. When citing an electronic database version of a treatise, include the electronic publisher name in the date parenthetical as you would with a state statute. Examples :

The works in the first two examples above have a special citation form provided by BB 15.8(a), and they cannot be cited using supra or hereinafter. If such a source has been cited in any form within the previous five footnotes, see RB 10.9, omit the publisher-and-date parenthetical but do not otherwise use a short form.

Please note that there may be circumstances when you need to cite an older version of a treatise. In such situations, you should cite to a print edition. Notify your SE if you are unsure which edition should be cited.
correct_examples: 35A Am. Jur. 2D Ferries § 55 (LexisNexis 2022). 2 C.J.S. Admiralty § 20 (West 2022).
3 Paul Goldstein, Goldstein on Copyright § 15.6.1 (Wolters Kluwer 2022).

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)
Supra with page reference (no note number)

bluebook_deviations.section_title: Preferred Versions of Common Works and Special Citation Forms
bluebook_deviations.rule_summary: 15.5: Preferred Versions of Common Works and Special Citation Forms
bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
15.5: Preferred Versions of Common Works and Special Citation Forms

SLR ’s preferred version of The Federalist is the 1961 edition edited by Clinton Rossiter. If you think there is a compelling reason to use a different version, please notify your SE. If the author cites a source which itself quotes or cites a different version of The Federalist , we would use that version in the citing or quoting parenthetical. See RB 1.8.

By SLR convention (and contrary to BB 15.10.1, ex. 8), a supra short-form citation to a Federalist essay should be formatted as follows:

You may use a supra short-form citation to refer to any essay in a particular edition of The Federalist if the piece you are editing has previously cited any other essay from the same edition. For instance, the above example would be correct even if footnote 17 gave a long-form citation to The Federalist No. 23 , written by Alexander Hamilton, rather than The Federalist No. 51 .

SLR ’s preferred version of Blackstone’s Commentaries is the last authorial edition: the London printing of the 12th edition (1793-95), available in SearchWorks through LLMC Digital.

SLR ’s preferred translation of the Bible is the New Revised Standard Version unless there is a compelling reason to cite another translation (such as the King James Version).

SLR ’s preferred version of the Code of Hammurabi is the 1904 translation by Robert Francis Harper. SLR has adopted the following citation format:

SLR ’s preferred version of Paradise Lost is the 2021 edition by Gordon Teskey. Example :

SLR has adopted the following citation form for Papal encyclicals:

For instance, the above example would be correct even if footnote 17 gave a long-form citation to The Federalist No. 23 , written by Alexander Hamilton, rather than The Federalist No. 51 .

deviations_from_bluebook.text: By SLR convention (and contrary to BB 15.10.1, ex. 8), a supra short-form citation to a Federalist essay should be formatted as follows:

correct_examples: The Federalist No. 51 (James Madison), supra note 17, at 319.
The Code of Hammurabi, King of Babylon § [sec no], at [page no] (Robert Francis Harper trans., 2d ed. 1904) (c. 2250 B.C.E.).

bluebook_deviations.full_rule_text:
15.6: Works in a Collection

SLR ’s preference is to use “ in ” for all works published in a collection—regardless of whether the collected material was originally published elsewhere. Cf. BB 15.5.2. When citing the individual work, use the same citation style and typeface as you would for any other source of that kind. Examples :

Use “ reprinted in ” only to note a convenient alternative location when citing a standalone work directly per BB 1.6(a)(ii). Example :
rule_paragraphs: 15.6: Works in a Collection

SLR ’s preference is to use “ in ” for all works published in a collection—regardless of whether the collected material was originally published elsewhere. Cf. BB 15.5.2. When citing the individual work, use the same citation style and typeface as you would for any other source of that kind. Examples :
Use “ reprinted in ” only to note a convenient alternative location when citing a standalone work directly per BB 1.6(a)(ii). Example :

deviations_from_bluebook.text: SLR ’s preference is to use “ in ” for all works published in a collection—regardless of whether the collected material was originally published elsewhere.

correct_examples: Marquis de Condorcet, Essay on the Application of Mathematics to the Theory of Decision-Making (1785), in Condorcet: Selected Writings 33, 48-49 (Keith M. Baker ed., 1976).

Memorandum from Robert F. Kennedy, Att’y Gen., to Ross R. Barnett, Governor of Miss. (Sept. 9, 1962), in U.S. Dep’t of Just., Pub. No. 9919, Centuries of Struggle: Civil and Equal Rights and the Long Arc of the Moral Universe 12 (2016), https://perma.cc/82FU-ZXCD.
P.J. Federico, Commentary on the New Patent Act , 35 U.S.C.A. 1 (West 1954), reprinted in 75 J. Pat. & Trademark Off. Soc’y 161, 176-77 (1993).
