clarifications.section_title: When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published
clarifications.rule_summary: 10.10: When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published
clarifications.full_rule_text:
10.10: When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published

When a case that is to be published in a print reporter has not yet been so published, cite an electronic database, preferably Westlaw. See BB 10.8.1. Additionally, make sure to check that the reporter has not been published since the last round of editing. If the publication is forthcoming, leave an [RCC] next to the citation. Example :

The L. Ed. and U.S.L.W. reporters (for Supreme Court cases) should be used only for cases that were actually omitted from the U.S. and S. Ct. reporters. Despite the fact that the Supreme Court itself cites slip opinions for recent cases, SLR would almost never do so since it prefers the electronic database version to the slip opinion. See RB 10.11.

Do not cite to "Preliminary Prints" of United States Reports ; use only the finalized versions, which as of July 2023 go up through Vol. 576. Ignore all higher volumes of United States Reports and cite to the next-most- preferred reporter instead (which will usually be S. Ct.). Unfortunately, Preliminary Prints are visually indistinguishable from published volumes, so it is best to be generally aware of the latest "valid" volume number. The MEs will announce when a new official volume is released.
rule_paragraphs: 10.10: When a Reporter Has Not Yet Been Published

When a case that is to be published in a print reporter has not yet been so published, cite an electronic database, preferably Westlaw. See BB 10.8.1. Additionally, make sure to check that the reporter has not been published since the last round of editing. If the publication is forthcoming, leave an [RCC] next to the citation. Example :

The L. Ed. and U.S.L.W. reporters (for Supreme Court cases) should be used only for cases that were actually omitted from the U.S. and S. Ct. reporters. Despite the fact that the Supreme Court itself cites slip opinions for recent cases, SLR would almost never do so since it prefers the electronic database version to the slip opinion. See RB 10.11.

Do not cite to "Preliminary Prints" of United States Reports ; use only the finalized versions, which as of July 2023 go up through Vol. 576. Ignore all higher volumes of United States Reports and cite to the next-most- preferred reporter instead (which will usually be S. Ct.). Unfortunately, Preliminary Prints are visually indistinguishable from published volumes, so it is best to be generally aware of the latest "valid" volume number. The MEs will announce when a new official volume is released.
correct_examples: See [RCC] Sveen v. Melin, No. 16-1432, 2018 WL 2767640, at *12-15 (U.S. June 11, 2018) (Gorsuch, J., dissenting).

clarifications.full_rule_text:
10.13: Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases

For citations that require docket numbers (for example, unreported cases ( see BB 10.8.1) or case documents ( see RB 10.6; BB 10.8.3)), include all docket numbers associated with the decision or case. List docket numbers in alphabetical or numerical order and use an ampersand before the final one. If there are more than three docket numbers, include only the first one and use "et al." Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 10.13: Docket Numbers for Consolidated Cases

For citations that require docket numbers (for example, unreported cases ( see BB 10.8.1) or case documents ( see RB 10.6; BB 10.8.3)), include all docket numbers associated with the decision or case. List docket numbers in alphabetical or numerical order and use an ampersand before the final one. If there are more than three docket numbers, include only the first one and use "et al." Examples :
correct_examples: Brief of Constitutional Law Scholars as Amici Curiae in Support of Petitioners at 8, Murphy v. NCAA, 138 S. Ct. 1461 (2018) (Nos. 16-476 & 16-477), 2017 WL 4004531.
Transcript of Oral Argument at 31-32, Epic Sys. Corp. v. Lewis, 138 S. Ct. 1612 (2018) (Nos. 16-285, 16-300 & 16-307), 2017 WL 4517132, at *32.
Reply Brief for Appellants at 16, League of United Latin Am. Citizens v. Perry, 548 U.S. 399 (2018) (Nos. 05-204 et al.), 2006 WL 457828.

regex_patterns.description: Et al. in short form citations
regex_patterns.redbook_note: RB 15.1 - First citation must include ALL authors

regex_patterns.description: Multiple authors with et al. (check if first citation)
regex_patterns.redbook_deviation: SLR requires ALL authors in first citation
regex_patterns.example: John Smith, Jane Doe et al.

regex_patterns.description: Docket number with initial digit before colon (remove per SLR)
Docket number, possibly with judge initials (remove initials per SLR)

clarifications.full_rule_text:
10.14: Short Forms for Early Reporters

Include an early reporter in a short-form citation, but not when using id. , if it would be included in the long form. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 10.14: Short Forms for Early Reporters
Include an early reporter in a short-form citation, but not when using id. , if it would be included in the long form. Example :
correct_examples: Correct : Marbury , 5 U.S. (1 Cranch) at 137; see also id. at 139.
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Marbury , 5 U.S. at 137.
Incorrect : Id. (1 Cranch) at 139.

clarifications.full_rule_text:
10.16: Signals Used as Verbs

When a signal such as "see" is used as a verb of a textual sentence in a footnote, and is therefore not italicized per BB 1.2(e), treat any case citation that follows according to the rule in BB 10.2 for "textual sentences." The fact that the verb happens to be "see" (or another signal) does not override the fact that the case citation becomes part of the sentence syntactically. Therefore, do italicize the case name and do not apply the additional abbreviation rules in BB 10.2.2. Example :

To be clear, this rule has no effect on citation clauses that are set off by commas, because those are not cases of "signal used as a verb." Example :
rule_paragraphs: 10.16: Signals Used as Verbs

When a signal such as "see" is used as a verb of a textual sentence in a footnote, and is therefore not italicized per BB 1.2(e), treat any case citation that follows according to the rule in BB 10.2 for "textual sentences." The fact that the verb happens to be "see" (or another signal) does not override the fact that the case citation becomes part of the sentence syntactically. Therefore, do italicize the case name and do not apply the additional abbreviation rules in BB 10.2.2. Example :
To be clear, this rule has no effect on citation clauses that are set off by commas, because those are not cases of "signal used as a verb." Example :
correct_examples: Correct : For an example of a well-known opinion, see Brown v. Board of Education , 347 U.S. 483 (1954).
Correct : Some opinions are well known, see, e.g. , Brown v. Bd. of Educ., 347 U.S. 483 (1954), while others are not, see, e.g. , Nat'l Ass'n of Mfrs. v. Dep't of Def., 138 S. Ct. 617 (2018).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : For an example of a well-known opinion, see Brown v. Bd. of Educ., 347 U.S. 483 (1954).

Incorrect : Some opinions are well known, see, e.g. , Brown v. Board of Education , 347 U.S. 483 (1954), while others are not, see, e.g. , National Ass'n of Manufacturers v. Department of Defense , 138 S. Ct. 617 (2018).

regex_patterns.description: See used as verb (not italicized, case name should be italicized)
regex_patterns.example: see Brown v. Board of Education

regex_patterns.description: See as citation signal (italicized, case name abbreviated)
regex_patterns.example: , see, e.g., Brown v. Bd. of Educ.

clarifications.full_rule_text:
10.17: Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand

If an entire subsequent history phrase is " rev'd and remanded " or " vacated and remanded ," omit " and remanded ."

But if the phrase continues, such as " rev'd and remanded on other grounds ," leave a note for your SE.
rule_paragraphs: 10.17: Subsequent History Phrases Involving Remand
If an entire subsequent history phrase is " rev'd and remanded " or " vacated and remanded ," omit " and remanded ."
But if the phrase continues, such as " rev'd and remanded on other grounds ," leave a note for your SE.

clarifications.full_rule_text:
10.18: Document Numbers in Federal Cases

For court documents in federal district court, bankruptcy court, or court of appeals cases, but not Supreme Court cases, append the ECF (Electronic Case File) number of the document to the citation if available, as allowed by BB 10.8.3. This number is assigned by PACER (the federal courts' document system) or a state equivalent, and you can find the sequential serial number in the leftmost column of the docket listing on Bloomberg. It also often appears as a "Document #" in the blue header of court documents downloaded from Bloomberg.

When including both a parallel citation to an electronic database (per RB 10.6) and an ECF number, the parallel citation should precede the ECF number. Please note that an ECF number is distinct from a docket number , which identifies an entire proceeding and appears after "No." in a citation. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 10.18: Document Numbers in Federal Cases

For court documents in federal district court, bankruptcy court, or court of appeals cases, but not Supreme Court cases, append the ECF (Electronic Case File) number of the document to the citation if available, as allowed by BB 10.8.3. This number is assigned by PACER (the federal courts' document system) or a state equivalent, and you can find the sequential serial number in the leftmost column of the docket listing on Bloomberg. It also often appears as a "Document #" in the blue header of court documents downloaded from Bloomberg.

When including both a parallel citation to an electronic database (per RB 10.6) and an ECF number, the parallel citation should precede the ECF number. Please note that an ECF number is distinct from a docket number , which identifies an entire proceeding and appears after "No." in a citation. Example :
correct_examples: Brief Amicus Curiae of Public Health Scholars & the American Public Health Ass'n at 4, Texas v. United States, 340 F. Supp. 3d 579 (N.D. Tex. 2018) (No. 18-cv-00167), 2018 WL 8262625, ECF No. 166.

clarifications.full_rule_text:
12.2: State Statutes

For state statutes, use the preferred version of the code noted in BB Table T1.3. For codes compiled by West or Lexis, use the database's current information for each particular law. Only include the name of the database if indicated by the entry in BB Table T1.3. Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 12.2: State Statutes

For state statutes, use the preferred version of the code noted in BB Table T1.3. For codes compiled by West or Lexis, use the database's current information for each particular law. Only include the name of the database if indicated by the entry in BB Table T1.3. Examples :
correct_examples: Cal. Harb. & Nav. Code § 134 (West 2022).
Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4585.01-.14 (LexisNexis 2022).

clarifications.full_rule_text:
12.4: Identical Digits for Statutes

To clarify BB 3.3(b), SLR convention is to retain identical digits when citing multiple sections within statutes. If you believe that omitting identical digits would improve readability without creating confusion, leave a comment for your SE. This rule does not apply to citations to multiple subsections.
rule_paragraphs: 12.4: Identical Digits for Statutes

To clarify BB 3.3(b), SLR convention is to retain identical digits when citing multiple sections within statutes. If you believe that omitting identical digits would improve readability without creating confusion, leave a comment for your SE. This rule does not apply to citations to multiple subsections.
correct_examples: Also correct : 28 U.S.C. § 1332(d)(1)-(3). Incorrect : 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331-32.
Correct : 42 U.S.C. §§ 300g-1 to -5, -7 [SE: I think we're okay omitting identical digits here even though 300g-1, 300g-2, etc. are their own sections. See the examples in BB 3.3(b).] .

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

clarifications.full_rule_text:
12.5: Citing the Internal Revenue Code

When citing Title 26 of the United States Code in a piece that involves substantial tax-related content, use "I.R.C." as permitted by BB 12.9.1. Otherwise, continue to cite this as "26 U.S.C." like the rest of the Code.
rule_paragraphs: 12.5: Citing the Internal Revenue Code

When citing Title 26 of the United States Code in a piece that involves substantial tax-related content, use "I.R.C." as permitted by BB 12.9.1. Otherwise, continue to cite this as "26 U.S.C." like the rest of the Code.

clarifications.full_rule_text:
12.6: Abbreviating Uniform Statutes

To clarify BB 12.9.4, all uniform statutes can be abbreviated according to BB Table T6; it does not matter whether they appear in Uniform Laws Annotated (U.L.A.). Example :
rule_paragraphs: 12.6: Abbreviating Uniform Statutes
To clarify BB 12.9.4, all uniform statutes can be abbreviated according to BB Table T6; it does not matter whether they appear in Uniform Laws Annotated (U.L.A.). Example :
correct_examples: Correct : Unif. Prob. Code § 2-108 (1983).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Uniform Probate Code § 2-108 (1983).

clarifications.full_rule_text:
12.7: Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances

Cite local ordinances—even those available only on websites—according to BB 12.9.2. Abbreviate the political subdivision and state name per BB Table T10 and the code name per BB Table T6. Do not provide the URL. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 12.7: Abbreviating Local Statutes or Ordinances

Cite local ordinances—even those available only on websites—according to BB 12.9.2. Abbreviate the political subdivision and state name per BB Table T10 and the code name per BB Table T6. Do not provide the URL. Example :
correct_examples: See, e.g. , S.F., Cal., Pub. Works Code § 2307.6(a) (2018).

clarifications.full_rule_text:
14.2: FTC Filings

SLR has created a citation format for FTC materials other than opinions, based on BB 14.3.2, BB 10.8.3, and BB Table T1.2. For an unpublished filing:

For a filing published in the FTC official reporter along with the FTC order, there’s no need to indicate that something is a complaint. Just follow BB 14.3.2.
rule_paragraphs: 14.2: FTC Filings
SLR has created a citation format for FTC materials other than opinions, based on BB 14.3.2, BB 10.8.3, and BB Table T1.2. For an unpublished filing:
For a filing published in the FTC official reporter along with the FTC order, there’s no need to indicate that something is a complaint. Just follow BB 14.3.2.
correct_examples: [Full document name (e.g., “Complaint, Request for Relief, and Order”)] [¶ pincite], [party name (per BB 14.3.1(a))], FTC File No. [number] ([date (of decision if one has been issued; otherwise of filing)]), [URL]. Example :
Complaint ¶ 6, Intuit Inc.., FTC File No. 192-3119 (Mar. 30, 2022), https://perma.cc/DW42-89R4 (“In truth, TurboTax is only free for some users.”).

clarifications.full_rule_text:
14.3: SEC Filings

Pincites for SEC filings follow the parenthetical identifying the form type and are set off by a comma. Cite section, paragraph, or item numbers where available. Use “at” only for page numbers. Example:

Expanding on BB Table T1.2, SLR has created the following citation format for exhibits included in SEC filings:

Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 14.3: SEC Filings

Pincites for SEC filings follow the parenthetical identifying the form type and are set off by a comma. Cite section, paragraph, or item numbers where available. Use “at” only for page numbers. Example:
Expanding on BB Table T1.2, SLR has created the following citation format for exhibits included in SEC filings:
Examples :
correct_examples: Alphabet Inc., Annual Report (Form 10-K), item 8, at 70 (Feb. 2, 2017).

[Company name (abbreviated according to BB Tables T6 & T10)], [full document name as indicated on the exhibit or table of exhibits] (Exhibit [number] to [form type]), [pincite] ([full date of filing]).
Bear Stearns Cos., Agreement and Plan of Merger, Dated March 16, 2008, by and Between the Bear Stearns Companies Inc. and JPMorgan Chase & Co. (Exhibit 2.1 to Form 8-K), § 1.4(c) (Mar. 20, 2008).
Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., Amended and Restated Bylaws of Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., Effective as of June 5, 2014 (Exhibit 3.2 to Form 10-Q), art. II, § 9 (June 6, 2014).

clarifications.section_title: Books, Reports, and Other Nonperiodic Materials

clarifications.full_rule_text:
15.3: Reports with Serial Numbers

Extrapolating from BB 15.7, always include a report number for a government document or other report that has a serial number.

For legislative, administrative, and executive reports, see BB 13.4, 14.2(d). Follow the citation format in BB 13.4(d) for Government Accountability Office (GAO) and Congressional Research Service (CRS) reports.
rule_paragraphs: 15.3: Reports with Serial Numbers
Extrapolating from BB 15.7, always include a report number for a government document or other report that has a serial number.

For legislative, administrative, and executive reports, see BB 13.4, 14.2(d). Follow the citation format in BB 13.4(d) for Government Accountability Office (GAO) and Congressional Research Service (CRS) reports.

clarifications.full_rule_text:
16.1: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines

A nonconsecutively paginated journal is a journal in which each issue starts on page one. A consecutively paginated journal has each volume start on page one, but each issue starts where the previous one left off.

For every periodical, you must check whether it is consecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.4, or nonconsecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.5. To check, find the periodical on a library database or the periodical’s website, pull up all issues from the same year or volume as the cited source , and see whether each issue starts on page one. The pagination schemes of some journals do change over time, so it is important to check the year or volume in which the cited source appears.

Once you confirm that a periodical is consecutively or nonconsecutively paginated, please note your findings in the Sourcepull spreadsheet so that future editors do not have to replicate the process.
rule_paragraphs: 16.1: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines

A nonconsecutively paginated journal is a journal in which each issue starts on page one. A consecutively paginated journal has each volume start on page one, but each issue starts where the previous one left off.

For every periodical, you must check whether it is consecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.4, or nonconsecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.5. To check, find the periodical on a library database or the periodical’s website, pull up all issues from the same year or volume as the cited source , and see whether each issue starts on page one. The pagination schemes of some journals do change over time, so it is important to check the year or volume in which the cited source appears.
Once you confirm that a periodical is consecutively or nonconsecutively paginated, please note your findings in the Sourcepull spreadsheet so that future editors do not have to replicate the process.

section_.rule_summary: The Redbook is the guide that Stanford Law Review ( SLR ) uses to clarify and expand on the conventions in The Bluebook . The Redbook is not comprehensive; it merely supplements—and sometimes overrules— The Bluebook . These rules allow SLR to maintain the same style conventions across everything it publishes, including both print and online pieces.
section_.full_rule_text:
The Redbook is the guide that Stanford Law Review ( SLR ) uses to clarify and expand on the conventions in The Bluebook . The Redbook is not comprehensive; it merely supplements—and sometimes overrules— The Bluebook . These rules allow SLR to maintain the same style conventions across everything it publishes, including both print and online pieces.

Edited by Volume 78 Managing Editors

Hierarchy of Rules

The following represents the hierarchy of sources for stylistic and editing rules that SLR follows:

These sources must be used in conjunction with one another. Each source on the list takes precedence over the sources below it.

Instances where The Redbook contradicts The Bluebook or The Chicago Manual of Style are marked in red font throughout this document. All other rules are clarifications but still supersede.

Comments and Annotations

Where you direct edits into the document on behalf of SLR , you will occasionally feel the desire to explain a particularly ambiguous cite or convention, seek clarification from an author, or flag a formatting issue. Where you do need to leave a comment in the document, do not use Microsoft Word's comment function . "Comments" for SLR purposes are in-line notations made directly into the text of the document:

*Not a real case.

It is important to place all comments directly next to the relevant text without any spaces between the comment and the text.

In practice : Anything you introduce into the document—including a comment directed at an SE or ME—is likely to find its way back to the author, even if by mistake. Therefore, all comments should be tactful. In case of doubt, leave your comment solely in the citecheck spreadsheet.

Please direct each comment to the appropriate person using annotation symbols to introduce the text:

AA (Author Attention)

Use [AA:] comments to request that the author (1) provide an additional citation; (2) provide 
        or confirm a pincite; or (3) rewrite an incomprehensible passage. Please phrase your comments as requests and provide suggestions 
        for improvement. Comments about the substantive correctness of a citation should go in the citecheck spreadsheet; the SE will turn 
        them into inline [AA:] comments if she decides it is necessary for the author to address the issue.

SE (Senior Editor)

Use [SE:] notations to alert your Senior Editor to minor problems that are better resolved by SLR staff rather than by the author and are more easily described inline than in the citecheck spreadsheet. Be sure to 
        (1) describe the nature of the problem; (2) suggest a solution; and, if it’s an editing concern, (3) direct the SE’s attention 
        to any portion of The Bluebook , The Redbook , or CMOS that may be relevant in resolving the issue. Do 
        not use [SE:] comments to raise substantive citechecking problems; those comments should be 
        left in the citecheck spreadsheet. If you think future editors would benefit from seeing the problem and its resolution, use the 
        citecheck spreadsheet. If the problem is serious or pervasive, please email your SE right away in addition to leaving an [SE:] comment or citecheck spreadsheet note.

ME (Managing Editor)

Use [ME:] notations to alert the Managing Editors about technical changes that need to be made to 
        the formatting of the article (for example, headers, footnote numbering, pagination, or anything that requires manual intervention 
        in Word). Do not adjust the formatting of the piece on your own, and never add or delete a footnote.

RCC (Re-Citecheck)

Use [RCC] notations to flag sources that could not be fully citechecked. Before adding an [RCC] comment, make a good-faith effort to find the source. This good-faith effort may include 
      (1) pulling, scanning, and uploading the source yourself (or submitting a Pull-and-Scan request form asking the Library to 
      do so); (2) requesting an interlibrary loan (ILL) through Crown Library (which you can find more information about in the 
      Member Editor Handbook); (3) asking the Executive Editors and Managing Editors to help you find a source; and (4) reaching 
      out to your SE to ask whether the author has a copy of the source. Do not reach out to the author directly by email unless 
      instructed to do so by your SE or someone on the Board. [RCC] notations should be used very 
      rarely, and once an [RCC] is added, you remain responsible for following up until the source 
      is properly located and citechecked.

Use [ME:] notations to alert the Managing Editors about technical changes that need to be made to 
        the formatting of the article (for example, headers, footnote numbering, pagination, or anything that requires manual intervention 
        in Word). Do not adjust the formatting of the piece on your own, and never add or delete a footnote.
RCC (Re-Citecheck)

Use [RCC] notations to flag sources that could not be fully citechecked. Before adding an [RCC] comment, make a good-faith effort to find the source. This good-faith effort may include 
      (1) pulling, scanning, and uploading the source yourself (or submitting a Pull-and-Scan request form asking the Library to 
      do so); (2) requesting an interlibrary loan (ILL) through Crown Library (which you can find more information about in the 
      Member Editor Handbook); (3) asking the Executive Editors and Managing Editors to help you find a source; and (4) reaching 
      out to your SE to ask whether the author has a copy of the source. Do not reach out to the author directly by email unless 
      instructed to do so by your SE or someone on the Board. [RCC] notations should be used very 
      rarely, and once an [RCC] is added, you remain responsible for following up until the source 
      is properly located and citechecked.

deviations_from_bluebook.text: Instances where The Redbook contradicts The Bluebook or The Chicago Manual of Style are marked in red font throughout this document.

correct_examples: The sky is blue. Doe v. Smith , 123 U.S. 1, 8 (1926). [SE: The source says that the sky is azure.]
The sky is blue. Doe v. Smith , 123 U.S. 1, 8 (1926) # [SE:  . . . .] (# means space. Do not do this).
structured_lists: 1. The Redbook ( RB )
2. The Bluebook: A Uniform System of Citation (22d ed. 2020) ( BB ), http://www.legalbluebook.com
3. The Chicago Manual of Style (17th ed. 2017) ( CMOS ), http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org
4. Merriam-Webster , http://www.m-w.com

regex_patterns.description: Pincite reference to page or page range

section_1_1.full_rule_text:
1.1: Quoting and Citing Parentheticals

SLR always requires a quoting parenthetical when the quoted source is itself quoting another source. If the author has forgotten to include a quoting parenthetical, you are responsible for adding one yourself, which may involve locating and pulling the quoted source, citechecking it, and uploading it to Box. However, SLR never requires a citing parenthetical. If the author wants to include a citing parenthetical, they may do so, but you need not add one or ask the author to add one.

For quoting and citing parentheticals, you are responsible for citechecking the quoted or cited source just as if the author had cited it directly. Occasionally, checking the quoted source is impracticable because it is impossible to retrieve. If you add a quoting parenthetical but are unable to citecheck the quoted source, please be sure (1) to leave an [RCC] in the document and (2) to flag the issue for your SE.
rule_paragraphs: 1.1: Quoting and Citing Parentheticals

SLR always requires a quoting parenthetical when the quoted source is itself quoting another source. If the author has forgotten to include a quoting parenthetical, you are responsible for adding one yourself, which may involve locating and pulling the quoted source, citechecking it, and uploading it to Box. However, SLR never requires a citing parenthetical. If the author wants to include a citing parenthetical, they may do so, but you need not add one or ask the author to add one.

For quoting and citing parentheticals, you are responsible for citechecking the quoted or cited source just as if the author had cited it directly. Occasionally, checking the quoted source is impracticable because it is impossible to retrieve. If you add a quoting parenthetical but are unable to citecheck the quoted source, please be sure (1) to leave an [RCC] in the document and (2) to flag the issue for your SE.

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

section_1_2.full_rule_text:
1.2: Identifying References

When a citation is used solely to identify a particular authority—rather than to support a factual or legal proposition—the footnote call number should appear immediately after the source (and after any punctuation mark except for a dash or colon, see BB 1.1(a)), in the text. Examples :

Please Note : When a source is introduced in a sentence but also supports its proposition, this rule does not apply. Include only a single footnote with the call number where it would otherwise appear.
rule_paragraphs: 1.2: Identifying References

When a citation is used solely to identify a particular authority—rather than to support a factual or legal proposition—the footnote call number should appear immediately after the source (and after any punctuation mark except for a dash or colon, see BB 1.1(a)), in the text. Examples :

Please Note : When a source is introduced in a sentence but also supports its proposition, this rule does not apply. Include only a single footnote with the call number where it would otherwise appear.
correct_examples: Justice Brandeis never knew about Brown v. Board of Education 1 or Between the World and Me ; 2 both were written after he died.
347 U.S. 483 (1954). Ta-Nehisi Coates, Between the World and Me (2015).
structured_lists: Ta-Nehisi Coates, Between the World and Me (2015).

section_1_3.full_rule_text:
1.3: Cases Named in Text

If a footnote supports text that names the case cited, the case name need not be repeated in the footnote, so long as the case name used in the text would be sufficient for the type of citation (long- or short-form) required in the corresponding footnote. See BB 10.9; see also RB 10.9. Thus, if a case is named in the text but has not been cited within the preceding five footnotes, the case must either be spelled out (1) in full in the text and omitted from the footnote or (2) in short in the text and in full in the footnote. Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 1.3: Cases Named in Text

If a footnote supports text that names the case cited, the case name need not be repeated in the footnote, so long as the case name used in the text would be sufficient for the type of citation (long- or short-form) required in the corresponding footnote. See BB 10.9; see also RB 10.9. Thus, if a case is named in the text but has not been cited within the preceding five footnotes, the case must either be spelled out (1) in full in the text and omitted from the footnote or (2) in short in the text and in full in the footnote. Examples :
correct_examples: Brown v. Board of Education cited psychological studies as part of its rationale. 1 This aspect of Brown has come under criticism from scholars. 2 Brown struck down racial segregation in public schools. 3 The Court also relied on psychological studies in its decision in Roper , which struck down capital punishment for persons convicted of crimes committed when they were under eighteen years of age. 4

347 U.S. 483, 494-95 (1954). See John Valery White, Brown v. Board of Education and the Origins of the Activist Insecurity in Civil Rights Law , 28 Ohio U. L. Rev. 303, 305 (2002). 347 U.S. at 495. Roper v. Simmons, 543 U.S. 551, 569-71 (2005).
structured_lists: See John Valery White, Brown v. Board of Education and the Origins of the Activist Insecurity in Civil Rights Law , 28 Ohio U. L. Rev. 303, 305 (2002).

section_1_4.full_rule_text:
1.4: Footnote Call Number Placement

With the exception of identifying references, see RB 1.2, footnote call numbers should generally be placed at the end of a sentence or clause. The call number follows any punctuation mark except the dash and the colon, both of which it precedes. BB 1.1(a). Generally, this includes a closing parenthesis. Examples :

When a parenthetical phrase occurs in a sentence, the call number should be placed before the closing parenthesis if the source only supports the text inside the parenthetical. Example :

Please Note : Although we do ask that you be on the lookout for propositions that need a citation added, please do not add, delete, or move footnote call numbers yourself. Otherwise, footnote numbering will not be consistent for everyone working on your article, and other technical chaos will ensue. If you need to move a call number a short distance (that is, not past another call number), just move the surrounding text instead. Denote any suggested footnote-related changes in [SE:] comments.
rule_paragraphs: 1.4: Footnote Call Number Placement

With the exception of identifying references, see RB 1.2, footnote call numbers should generally be placed at the end of a sentence or clause. The call number follows any punctuation mark except the dash and the colon, both of which it precedes. BB 1.1(a). Generally, this includes a closing parenthesis. Examples :
When a parenthetical phrase occurs in a sentence, the call number should be placed before the closing parenthesis if the source only supports the text inside the parenthetical. Example :

Please Note : Although we do ask that you be on the lookout for propositions that need a citation added, please do not add, delete, or move footnote call numbers yourself. Otherwise, footnote numbering will not be consistent for everyone working on your article, and other technical chaos will ensue. If you need to move a call number a short distance (that is, not past another call number), just move the surrounding text instead. Denote any suggested footnote-related changes in [SE:] comments.
correct_examples: " Marbury ," Laura said, "is simply amazing." 1 (She retracted this in a later statement.) 2 The semiconductor changed everything; 3 it is vital to modern computing.
Some believe that President Warren G. Harding's sudden death was caused by poisoning 4 —his doctors, though, insisted that the cause was heart failure. 5
Speiser overturned a state requirement that veterans declare an oath to the government to be eligible for a tax exemption (initiating the line of cases known as "unconstitutional conditions" 1 ).

[Citation to a source that supports the parenthetical proposition that Speiser initiated the "unconstitutional conditions" doctrine but does not support the outside description of Speiser 's holding.]
structured_lists: [Citation to a source that supports the parenthetical proposition that Speiser initiated the "unconstitutional conditions" doctrine but does not support the outside description of Speiser 's holding.]

section_1_6.section_title: Multiple Sources Following a Signal as a Verb
section_1_6.rule_summary: 1.6: Multiple Sources Following a Signal as a Verb
section_1_6.full_rule_text:
1.6: Multiple Sources Following a Signal as a Verb

When multiple sources are attached to a textual signal, insert semicolons to separate them, add an "and" before the final source, and finish with a period. This rule applies even if only two sources are listed. If switching to a new signal, begin a new citation sentence. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 1.6: Multiple Sources Following a Signal as a Verb

When multiple sources are attached to a textual signal, insert semicolons to separate them, add an "and" before the final source, and finish with a period. This rule applies even if only two sources are listed. If switching to a new signal, begin a new citation sentence. Example :
correct_examples: For a discussion of fun places to eat, see Example 1; Example 2; and Example 3. See also Example 4 (a particularly fun place to eat); Example 5 (same). For a discussion of the best theaters, see, for example, Example 6; and Example 7.

regex_patterns.description: See used as verb (not italicized, case name should be italicized)
regex_patterns.example: see Brown v. Board of Education

regex_patterns.description: See as citation signal (italicized, case name abbreviated)
regex_patterns.example: , see, e.g., Brown v. Bd. of Educ.

section_1_7.section_title: When a Source Quotes or Cites Multiple Sources
section_1_7.rule_summary: 1.7: When a Source Quotes or Cites Multiple Sources
section_1_7.full_rule_text:
1.7: When a Source Quotes or Cites Multiple Sources

When a source quotes multiple sources, follow BB 1.5(b)'s "first quoting," "then quoting" rule. Include "and" before the final source even if there are only two. Example :

When a source cites multiple sources and the author has chosen to include a citing parenthetical ( see RB 1.1), list the authorities in the order in which they were cited, separated by semicolons, with an "and" before the final source even if there are only two. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 1.7: When a Source Quotes or Cites Multiple Sources
When a source quotes multiple sources, follow BB 1.5(b)'s "first quoting," "then quoting" rule. Include "and" before the final source even if there are only two. Example :

When a source cites multiple sources and the author has chosen to include a citing parenthetical ( see RB 1.1), list the authorities in the order in which they were cited, separated by semicolons, with an "and" before the final source even if there are only two. Example :
correct_examples: Collin Fredricks, Everything's Better in Texas 47-48 (2024) (first quoting Source 1; and then quoting Source 2).
See Bella M. Ryb, From SCOTUS Clinic to SLR : How to Do It All, Effortlessly , 76 Stan. L. Rev. 1022, 1075 (2024) (citing Source 1; and Source 2).

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

section_1_9.full_rule_text:
1.9: Nested Parentheticals

When an explanatory parenthetical has text that itself requires a parenthetical, the parentheticals should be nested. See BB 10.6.4. This rule applies to all types of sources, not only to cases. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 1.9: Nested Parentheticals

When an explanatory parenthetical has text that itself requires a parenthetical, the parentheticals should be nested. See BB 10.6.4. This rule applies to all types of sources, not only to cases. Example :
correct_examples: Devin M. Flynn, Why the Candidate Exercise Needs More Schitt's Creek, 76 Stan. L. Rev. 721, 736 (2024)
("'Th[ose] crows have eyes,' and they're looking for Honor Code violations." (alteration in original) (quoting The Crows Have Eyes 3: The Crowening (Meg Harrington dir., 2018))).

section_1_10.full_rule_text:
1.10: Length of Explanatory Parentheticals

Explanatory parentheticals featuring present participial phrases such as "(arguing that . . . )," see BB 1.5(a)(i), may never be longer than a single sentence of a reasonable length. If the author wants to include more information, they must work it into the text (in the body of the piece or a footnote). Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 1.10: Length of Explanatory Parentheticals

Explanatory parentheticals featuring present participial phrases such as "(arguing that . . . )," see BB 1.5(a)(i), may never be longer than a single sentence of a reasonable length. If the author wants to include more information, they must work it into the text (in the body of the piece or a footnote). Examples :
correct_examples: Correct : Horace P. Payne III, Tales of a Library Warden: Perspective from the Second Floor , 76 Stan. L. Rev. 45, 47 (2024) (chronicling the trials and tribulations of life as the library watchdog). Payne's central argument is based on personal experience overseeing the library's nighttime operations. See id. Also correct : Horace P. Payne III, Tales of a Library Warden: Perspective from the Second Floor , 76 Stan. L. Rev. 45, 47 (2024) (chronicling the trials and tribulations of life as the library watchdog based on personal experience overseeing the library's nighttime operations).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Horace P. Payne III, Tales of a Library Warden: Perspective from the Second Floor , 76 Stan. L. Rev. 45, 47 (2024) (chronicling the trials and tribulations of life as the library watchdog. Payne's central argument is based on personal experience overseeing the library's nighttime operations.).

regex_patterns.description: Quoting parenthetical (SLR requires when source quotes another)

section_16_4.full_rule_text:
16.4: Special Reports in Newspapers

Separately paginated special reports should generally be cited in accordance with BB 15 (or, if not substantial enough to qualify for BB 15, then as a miscellaneous document, see RB 18.7). If a special report contains multiple articles, treat each article like a shorter work within a collection in accordance with BB 15.5.1. Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 16.4: Special Reports in Newspapers

Separately paginated special reports should generally be cited in accordance with BB 15 (or, if not substantial enough to qualify for BB 15, then as a miscellaneous document, see RB 18.7). If a special report contains multiple articles, treat each article like a shorter work within a collection in accordance with BB 15.5.1. Examples :
correct_examples: Correct : Chip Dale, Institutions and Counterparty Risk , in Fin. Times, Asset Servicing 4, 9 (2010).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Chip Dale, Special Report, Institutions and Counterparty Risk , Fin. Times , Oct. 18, 2010, at 4.

section_16_5.full_rule_text:
16.5: Citing Abstracts

SLR does not cite abstracts. If the author has cited or quoted an abstract, either (1) change the pincite to wherever in the article the appropriate citation would be or (2) ask the author to do so. If the author has quoted a part of the abstract and the same language never appears later in the article, leave an AA note asking them to pick a different quotation. If the author cites the abstract because they are making a point about what the article is generally about, a citation to the introduction or conclusion will usually work as a substitute. If the citation to the introduction or conclusion addresses a point that goes beyond the general thrust of the article, you will need to find a new citation within the body of the article.
rule_paragraphs: 16.5: Citing Abstracts

SLR does not cite abstracts. If the author has cited or quoted an abstract, either (1) change the pincite to wherever in the article the appropriate citation would be or (2) ask the author to do so. If the author has quoted a part of the abstract and the same language never appears later in the article, leave an AA note asking them to pick a different quotation. If the author cites the abstract because they are making a point about what the article is generally about, a citation to the introduction or conclusion will usually work as a substitute. If the citation to the introduction or conclusion addresses a point that goes beyond the general thrust of the article, you will need to find a new citation within the body of the article.

Pincite reference to page or page range

section_16_6.full_rule_text:
16.6: Checking for Special Designations

Per BB 16.7, always check whether a piece appearing in a law review is a note, comment, or other student- written work; book review; or other specially designated work (that is, anything that is not an “article”). Please be sure to include this designation in the citation. Example :

Signs that a piece is a student-written work include that (1) the author’s name appears at the end, rather than the beginning, of a piece; (2) there is no author bio footnote on the first page; and/or (3) there is such a footnote, and the author is identified as a student or recent graduate.

If you are unsure whether the piece is an article or another type of piece, check the Table of Contents to see how it is described there and leave a comment for your SE.

This rule also applies to other periodicals. For newspapers (including those available online), check whether the piece is an editorial, opinion, or letter to the editor per BB 16.6(a). Example :
rule_paragraphs: 16.6: Checking for Special Designations

Per BB 16.7, always check whether a piece appearing in a law review is a note, comment, or other student- written work; book review; or other specially designated work (that is, anything that is not an “article”). Please be sure to include this designation in the citation. Example :

Signs that a piece is a student-written work include that (1) the author’s name appears at the end, rather than the beginning, of a piece; (2) there is no author bio footnote on the first page; and/or (3) there is such a footnote, and the author is identified as a student or recent graduate.
If you are unsure whether the piece is an article or another type of piece, check the Table of Contents to see how it is described there and leave a comment for your SE.
This rule also applies to other periodicals. For newspapers (including those available online), check whether the piece is an editorial, opinion, or letter to the editor per BB 16.6(a). Example :
correct_examples: Jamie D. Halper, Note, Friends, Classmates, Alumni, Lend Me Your Student Notes , 76 Stan. L. Rev. 1, 3 (2024) (noting the Note’s notable contributions to the scholarship discussing noteworthy notations).

Elizabeth W. Tarbell, Letter to the Editor, No Chico for Me , S.F. Chron. (June 5, 2023), https://perma.cc/SS2H-TMFA (urging members of SLR to refer to Horace Preston Payne III by his full legal name).

section_17_1.full_rule_text:
17.1: SSRN Publications

SLR cites papers on SSRN only as a last resort. If you encounter an SSRN citation for a forthcoming or unpublished paper, check to see whether it is published elsewhere.
rule_paragraphs: 17.1: SSRN Publications
SLR cites papers on SSRN only as a last resort. If you encounter an SSRN citation for a forthcoming or unpublished paper, check to see whether it is published elsewhere.

section_18_1.full_rule_text:
18.1: URLs

In all citations to internet sources, SLR includes an archival link. Contrary to BB 18.2.1(d), SLR never includes both an original and an archival link. SLR uses Perma.cc to archive internet sources. For more information about Perma.cc and its role in combating link rot, see https://perma.cc.

The MEs will convert all URLs to Perma.cc links between Round 2 and Galley Night. During Galley Night, you are responsible for checking the Perma.cc links to ensure that they are working. You do not need to alter them otherwise.

Where a (last visited) parenthetical would otherwise be required in a citation under BB 18.2.2(c)—that is, when there is no date provided on the website itself—it should be replaced with an (archived) parenthetical indicating the Perma.cc capture date. Examples :

If a webpage contains both the time and date of its original publication and the time and date it was updated (as is sometimes the case with news materials), include the latter in an (updated [date]) parenthetical in the same place you would put the date parenthetical otherwise (that is, before the URL). If the webpage is periodically updated and notes the date it was “last updated” or “last modified,” include that date in a (last updated [date]) parenthetical that replaces the archived date parenthetical (that is, after the URL), per BB 18.2.2(c). Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 18.1: URLs

If the webpage is periodically updated and notes the date it was “last updated” or “last modified,” include that date in a (last updated [date]) parenthetical that replaces the archived date parenthetical (that is, after the URL), per BB 18.2.2(c). Examples :

correct_examples: Correct : Isaac W. Shapiro, A New Era for Bumble Bee Tuna , Applied Ichthyology Q. (June 30, 2023, 3:04 AM PDT), https://perma.cc/NL8B-AFTG (discussing beekeeping’s lessons for the aquaculture industry).
Correct : Conrad Sproul, A Guide to Having Your Online Submission Published , Phat Chance Blog , https://perma.cc/5BJC-B6XV (archived July 7, 2020).
Correct : Andrew J. Park, Caffeination at SLS: What to Do When the Free Coffee Machine is Broken , Stan. Pub. Prot. Cmty. Comm’n (updated Aug. 20, 2023), https://perma.cc/65KH-59EN.
Correct : Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, Outlook Notifications Haunt Our Dreams , Exec. Ed. Dig. , https://perma.cc/AX3N-AXAJ (last updated Aug. 22, 2023).

section_18_2.section_title: Avoiding Repetitious Author Names or Page Titles
section_18_2.rule_summary: 18.2: Avoiding Repetitious Author Names or Page Titles
section_18_2.full_rule_text:
18.2: Avoiding Repetitious Author Names or Page Titles

If there would be repetition between the author name, the page title, and/or the main page title, the general rule is to leave the main page title and any other nonrepetitive information. Two common scenarios:

Institutional author clear from main page title : If the institutional author is the same as the owner of the main page and the owner of the main page is clear from the main page title, omit the name of the institutional author and retain the main page title in small caps. See BB 18.2.2(a). Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 18.2: Avoiding Repetitious Author Names or Page Titles

If there would be repetition between the author name, the page title, and/or the main page title, the general rule is to leave the main page title and any other nonrepetitive information. Two common scenarios:

Institutional author clear from main page title : If the institutional author is the same as the owner of the main page and the owner of the main page is clear from the main page title, omit the name of the institutional author and retain the main page title in small caps. See BB 18.2.2(a). Examples :
correct_examples: Correct : Directors, Then and Now , FBI , https://perma.cc/C4YL-47JD (archived July 7, 2017).
Correct : See Fed. Jud. Ctr. , https://perma.cc/524A-BHQD (archived July 7, 2017).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : FBI, Directors, Then and Now , FBI , https://perma.cc/C4YL-47JD (archived July 7, 2017). Citation to main page : If the citation is to the main page itself, there’s no need to include an italicized page title; only the abbreviated main page title in small caps need be included. See BB 18.2.2(b)(i). Examples :

Incorrect : See Federal Judicial Center , Fed. Jud. Ctr. , https://perma.cc/524A-BHQD (archived July 7, 2017). Incorrect : See Homepage , Fed. Jud. Ctr. , https://perma.cc/524A-BHQD (archived July 7, 2017).

section_18_3.section_title: Omitting Words in Main Page Titles
section_18_3.rule_summary: 18.3: Omitting Words in Main Page Titles
section_18_3.full_rule_text:
18.3: Omitting Words in Main Page Titles

To clarify BB 18.2.2(b)(i), omit the words “a,” “at,” “in,” “of,” and “the” (but retain the word “on”) in main page titles. Do so regardless of whether the page is a periodical. If the resulting title would be unrecognizable or patently asinine (for example, “Above the Law” becoming “ Above L. ”), leave a comment for your SE. See RB 22.11.
rule_paragraphs: 18.3: Omitting Words in Main Page Titles

To clarify BB 18.2.2(b)(i), omit the words “a,” “at,” “in,” “of,” and “the” (but retain the word “on”) in main page titles. Do so regardless of whether the page is a periodical. If the resulting title would be unrecognizable or patently asinine (for example, “Above the Law” becoming “ Above L. ”), leave a comment for your SE. See RB 22.11.
correct_examples: Correct : Off. of the Att’y Gen., About the Office , U.S. Dep’t Just. , https://perma.cc/XA5J-G2V2 (last updated Mar. 12, 2021).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Off. of the Att’y Gen., About the Office , U.S. Dep’t of Just. , https://perma.cc/XA5J-G2V2 (last updated Mar. 12, 2021).

section_18_4.full_rule_text:
18.4: Dates and Times

Include all of the date/time information provided by the website, formatted by analogy with the following example: (Feb. 1, 2004, 3:56:24 PM CST). If the website does not provide all of the information, include whatever information is available. Note that time zones such as PST, PDT, and PT are all valid, and all mean different things; thus, do not “correct” time zones except to remove periods. Example :

If the webpage provides a time in 24-hour format, translate the time into AM/PM format. Example :

If the webpage does not provide any date/time information, the Managing Editors will include the date the Perma.cc record was created in a parenthetical after the URL. SLR never uses “last visited” parentheticals. When you encounter a source without any date/time information, please insert an “archived” parenthetical but leave the date blank. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 18.4: Dates and Times

SLR never uses “last visited” parentheticals. When you encounter a source without any date/time information, please insert an “archived” parenthetical but leave the date blank. Example :

Correct : Christopher Huberty, They Both Have a Salesforce Tower: Why There Are No Discernible Differences Between Indianapolis and San Francisco , Architectural Dig. (May 10, 2022, 11:40 PM EDT), https://perma.cc/VM8A-QC5P.
Correct : Julia Gokhberg, Please Come to the Symposium , Please , https://perma.cc/ZHR5-5RP4 (archived Sept. 28, 2023).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Jennifer L. Portis, Multimedia? More Like Multi-meme-dia , NBC News (Jan. 7, 2022, 7:03 PM P.S.T.), https://perma.cc/TR8M-QQR8 (advocating for creation of a “Meme-ber Editor” board position).

Incorrect : Christopher Huberty, They Both Have a Salesforce Tower: Why There Are No Discernible Differences Between Indianapolis and San Francisco , Architectural Dig. (May 10, 2022, 23:40 EDT), https://perma.cc/VM8A-QC5P.

rule_paragraphs: 1.11: Grammar of Explanatory Parentheticals
correct_examples: Correct : Zwuickler v. Koota, 389 U.S. 241, 251-52 (1967) (discussing the "principles" of the Fourteenth Amendment).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Zwuickler v. Koota, 389 U.S. 241, 251-52 (1967) (discussing "principles" of Fourteenth Amendment).

section_18_5.full_rule_text:
18.5: Parallel Citations to Internet Sources

SLR encourages citations to internet sources whenever the printed source might be difficult for a reader to access. When including a parallel citation, the URL should be placed according to RB 1.16.
rule_paragraphs: 18.5: Parallel Citations to Internet Sources
SLR encourages citations to internet sources whenever the printed source might be difficult for a reader to access. When including a parallel citation, the URL should be placed according to RB 1.16.

section_18_6.full_rule_text:
18.6: Location Parentheticals for Websites

If a source is hard to find once you visit the URL in the citation, please insert a “to locate” parenthetical to help direct the reader to the particular information being cited. See BB 18.2.2(d). Example :
rule_paragraphs: 18.6: Location Parentheticals for Websites

If a source is hard to find once you visit the URL in the citation, please insert a “to locate” parenthetical to help direct the reader to the particular information being cited. See BB 18.2.2(d). Example :
correct_examples: Archived Public Data Files: FY 2013 , U.S. Soc. Sec. Admin. , https://perma.cc/Y39C-7P3R (archived July 7, 2017) (to locate, select “View the live page,” then select the “FY 2013” tab, follow the “ALJ Disposition Data” hyperlink, and select “September 2013”).

section_18_7.full_rule_text:
18.7: Miscellaneous Documents in PDF Form

The foregoing sections apply to webpages; online PDFs are treated differently. The Bluebook does not provide a format for miscellaneous or informal PDF documents that are not “reports” per BB 15, so SLR has developed its own format. When a document in PDF form is available only (or primarily) online but is not a website or other document outlined in BB 17.2, it is likely a miscellaneous document.

Cite a miscellaneous document as a report, but use roman text in lieu of small caps. Example :

For an example of a miscellaneous document, see Sup. Ct. of the State of N.Y., Cnty. of N.Y., Parenting Plan (2013), https://perma.cc/M87K-AUJT. When considering whether something is a report or miscellaneous document, keep in mind the types of sources that receive small caps (books) and those that receive roman text (working papers). Below are several criteria to help you decide whether something is a report or miscellaneous document. Whichever you choose, leave an SE note explaining your reasoning.
rule_paragraphs: 18.7: Miscellaneous Documents in PDF Form

When a document in PDF form is available only (or primarily) online but is not a website or other document outlined in BB 17.2, it is likely a miscellaneous document.
Cite a miscellaneous document as a report, but use roman text in lieu of small caps. Example :

For an example of a miscellaneous document, see Sup. Ct. of the State of N.Y., Cnty. of N.Y., Parenting Plan (2013), https://perma.cc/M87K-AUJT. When considering whether something is a report or miscellaneous document, keep in mind the types of sources that receive small caps (books) and those that receive roman text (working papers). incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Bella M. Ryb, Presidential Platitudes 4-11 (2020), https://perma.cc/Y3AB-RBCK.
structured_lists: Created by, for, or with the help of a government, corporation, organization, or other well-known entity
Often have serial numbers
Usually quite long
Address a primary area of research or research question and involve analysis and/or empirical findings
Formal in appearance
Can be created by anyone
Usually have no serial number
May be as short as a single page
Can be entirely contentless or merely be directing the public to information without conducting any new research or analysis
Informal in appearance

section_18_8.full_rule_text:
18.8: Dates for Online PDFs

For PDFs (whether qualifying as a report or a miscellaneous document, see RB 18.7), include only the year on the document, even if there is more specific date information available. This is different from the rule for citations to webpages, where SLR includes all date and time information given on the page. Cf. RB 18.4. If there is no date available, use an (n.d.) parenthetical instead. Cf. BB 15.4(c). Do not include the archival date, and do not impute a date based on context clues (for example, the academic or fiscal year to which a document refers, which may not in fact be the date when the document was created). Examples :

The same principles apply for PDFs cited as reports under BB 15.

section_18_9.full_rule_text:
18.9: Movies

Contrary to BB 18.6, SLR includes the director(s) rather than the production company in citations to films. Citations should follow the general format of: [ Movie Title ([Director’s Name] dir., [year]). See generally Rafi Reznik, Essay, The Auteur as Editor , 73 Stan. L. Rev. Online (2020). Example :

section_21_1.full_rule_text:
21.1: Names in Treaty Titles

Where the title of a treaty includes the names of the parties to the treaty, omit that portion from the title, unless doing so would shorten the treaty name to “Treaty” or something similar. Place the names of the parties later in the citation in accordance with BB 21.4.2. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 21.1: Names in Treaty Titles

Where the title of a treaty includes the names of the parties to the treaty, omit that portion from the title, unless doing so would shorten the treaty name to “Treaty” or something similar. Place the names of the parties later in the citation in accordance with BB 21.4.2. Example :
correct_examples: Correct : Definitive Treaty of Peace, Gr. Brit.-U.S., art. IV, Sept. 3, 1783, 8 Stat. 80.
But: Treaty Between the United States of America and the French Republic, Fr.-U.S., Apr. 30, 1803, 8 Stat. 200.
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Definitive Treaty of Peace Between the United States and His Britannic Majesty, Gr. Brit.-U.S., art. IV, Sept. 3, 1783, 8 Stat. 80.

section_22_1.full_rule_text:
22.1: Spelling

Always use Merriam-Webster ’s preferred spelling. Do not simply trust your Microsoft Word dictionary, which in many cases does not conform to Merriam-Webster . For more obscure words, look to the Oxford English Dictionary for guidance—but if the word does not appear in Merriam-Webster , leave a comment for your SE.

SLR prefers the U.S. spelling of words over foreign spellings: Use “honor” instead of “honour” and “toward” instead of “towards.” However, these preferences apply only to the author’s own words, not to quoted material, which should be left as originally written without [sic]. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 22.1: Spelling

Always use Merriam-Webster ’s preferred spelling. Do not simply trust your Microsoft Word dictionary, which in many cases does not conform to Merriam-Webster . For more obscure words, look to the Oxford English Dictionary for guidance—but if the word does not appear in Merriam-Webster , leave a comment for your SE.

SLR prefers the U.S. spelling of words over foreign spellings: Use “honor” instead of “honour” and “toward” instead of “towards.” However, these preferences apply only to the author’s own words, not to quoted material, which should be left as originally written without [sic]. See RB 5.4.

section_22_2.full_rule_text:
22.2: Plurals

For general guidance on creating plurals, consult CMOS 7.5-.15. For plurals of acronyms or periods of time, do not add an apostrophe (for example, use “ATVs” rather than “ATV’s” and “the 1980s” rather than “the 1980’s”).
rule_paragraphs: 22.2: Plurals

For general guidance on creating plurals, consult CMOS 7.5-.15. For plurals of acronyms or periods of time, do not add an apostrophe (for example, use “ATVs” rather than “ATV’s” and “the 1980s” rather than “the 1980’s”).

section_1_13.section_title: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization
section_1_13.rule_summary: 1.13: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization
section_1_13.full_rule_text:
1.13: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization

SLR uses (emphasis omitted) when the cited source uses formatting to emphasize a word or phrase and the author wants to omit that emphasis. If the cited source contains multiple separate emphases and the author omits all of them, simply use (emphasis omitted), not (emphases omitted). Example :

SLR allows (capitalization altered) in lieu of brackets to indicate altered capitalization in a direct quotation when doing so would significantly improve readability. Drop an [SE:] comment if you think (capitalization altered) might be appropriate but the author has not yet suggested it. Examples :

Do not indicate changes to the typography or layout of quoted material that do not serve to remove emphasis. See RB 5.4; cf. CMOS 13.8. SLR does not use (formatting altered), (italics omitted), or (bolding omitted). If the typographical change does remove substantive emphasis, use (emphasis omitted). Example :
rule_paragraphs: 1.13: Parentheticals Indicating Alterations to Emphasis and Capitalization

SLR uses (emphasis omitted) when the cited source uses formatting to emphasize a word or phrase and the author wants to omit that emphasis. If the cited source contains multiple separate emphases and the author omits all of them, simply use (emphasis omitted), not (emphases omitted). Example :

SLR allows (capitalization altered) in lieu of brackets to indicate altered capitalization in a direct quotation when doing so would significantly improve readability. Drop an [SE:] comment if you think (capitalization altered) might be appropriate but the author has not yet suggested it. Examples :

Do not indicate changes to the typography or layout of quoted material that do not serve to remove emphasis. See RB 5.4; cf. CMOS 13.8. SLR does not use (formatting altered), (italics omitted), or (bolding omitted). If the typographical change does remove substantive emphasis, use (emphasis omitted). Example :
correct_examples: Original text :     One arises from a desertion of duty, and the other dessert fails to rise.
Citation : Garrett M. Wen, Musings on Torts and Tortes , 75 Stan. L. Rev. 104, 128-29 (2023) ("One arises from a desertion of duty, and the other dessert fails to rise." (emphasis omitted)).
Original text :   No Additional Process Is Due.

Correct : Brief of Stanford University at 24, Leland Stanford Junior Univ. v. Stanford L. Rev., 904 F.3d 126 (9th Cir. 2020) (No. 18-837), 2020 LEXIS App. 953154, at *15 (arguing that "no additional process is due" (capitalization altered)).

Also correct : Brief of Stanford University at 24, Leland Stanford Junior Univ. v. Stanford L. Rev., 904 F.3d 126 (9th Cir. 2020) (No. 18-837), 2020 LEXIS App. 953154, at *15 (arguing that "[n]o [a]dditional [p]rocess [i]s [d]ue" [SE: Consider (capitalization altered).] ).
Original text : Look, we can't all release two new albums during quarantine. If we could, we would all be the greatest songwriters of our generation.
Correct : Madison A. Burson, We'll Never Find Another Like Taylor: The Greatest Songwriter of Our Generation 41 (2024) (observing that "we can't all release two new albums during quarantine").

section_22_3.full_rule_text:
22.3: Hyphenation

section_22_4.full_rule_text:
22.4: Quotation Marks and Apostrophes

SLR exclusively uses smart/curly quotes (for example, “and” or “a husky’s howl”) to designate quoted material; SLR never uses straight quotes or apostrophes (for example, "and" or "a husky's howl").

Use caution when applying smart/curly quotes to case names beginning with “Mc” or “Mac.” The apostrophe in these case names is a “turned comma,” and should face in the opposite direction of what Word’s smart quotes feature wants. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 22.4: Quotation Marks and Apostrophes
SLR exclusively uses smart/curly quotes (for example, “and” or “a husky’s howl”) to designate quoted material; SLR never uses straight quotes or apostrophes (for example, "and" or "a husky's howl").

Use caution when applying smart/curly quotes to case names beginning with “Mc” or “Mac.” The apostrophe in these case names is a “turned comma,” and should face in the opposite direction of what Word’s smart quotes feature wants. Example :
correct_examples: Correct : Johnson v. M‘Intosh, 21 U.S. (7 Wheat.) 543 (1823).
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Johnson v. M’Intosh, 21 U.S. (7 Wheat.) 543 (1823).

section_22_5.full_rule_text:
22.5: Commas

SLR defers to the author’s preference regarding commas unless the use violates one of the three rules laid out below or is clearly grammatically incorrect.

Serial (Oxford) comma : SLR uses a comma after the penultimate item in a series. CMOS 6.19; see also CMOS 6.60; cf. O’Connor v. Oakhurst Dairy, 851 F.3d 69, 70 (1st Cir. 2017) (“For want of a comma, we have this case.”). But see Vampire Weekend, Oxford Comma , on Vampire Weekend (XL Recordings 2008). Example :

Initial conjunctions : For the purposes of readability and clarity, commas should not be used to set off initial conjunctions of three or fewer letters (“so,” “and,” “but,” and “yet”). If an initial conjunction of three or fewer letters is followed by a parenthetical phrase that is itself normally set off by commas, defer to the author’s preference (but flag for your SE so that they can ensure consistency throughout). Examples :

“That” and dependent clauses: Omit a comma after “that” when it introduces a dependent clause. Cf. CMOS 6.26.

Example :
rule_paragraphs: 22.5: Commas
SLR defers to the author’s preference regarding commas unless the use violates one of the three rules laid out below or is clearly grammatically incorrect.

Serial (Oxford) comma : SLR uses a comma after the penultimate item in a series. CMOS 6.19; see also CMOS 6.60; cf. O’Connor v. Oakhurst Dairy, 851 F.3d 69, 70 (1st Cir. 2017) (“For want of a comma, we have this case.”). But see Vampire Weekend, Oxford Comma , on Vampire Weekend (XL Recordings 2008). Example :

Initial conjunctions : For the purposes of readability and clarity, commas should not be used to set off initial conjunctions of three or fewer letters (“so,” “and,” “but,” and “yet”). If an initial conjunction of three or fewer letters is followed by a parenthetical phrase that is itself normally set off by commas, defer to the author’s preference (but flag for your SE so that they can ensure consistency throughout). Examples :
“That” and dependent clauses: Omit a comma after “that” when it introduces a dependent clause. Cf. CMOS 6.26.
Example :
correct_examples: Correct : I’d like to thank my parents, Britney Spears, and Nelson Mandela.
Correct : And don’t call me Shirley.
Correct : But, on the other hand, I can’t stop you.
Also correct : But on the other hand, I can’t stop you.
Correct : The court held that although hot dogs could be considered sandwiches, a hot dog does not fall within the plain (or “cocktail party”) meaning of “sandwich.”
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : I’d like to thank my parents, Britney Spears and Nelson Mandela.
Incorrect : And, don’t call me Shirley.
Incorrect : The court held that, although hot dogs could be considered sandwiches, a hot dog does not fall within the plain (or “cocktail party”) meaning of “sandwich.”

section_22_6.full_rule_text:
22.6: Hyphens and Dashes

SLR uses hyphens (that is, “-”) and em dashes (that is, “—”) in accordance with the rules and examples of The

Bluebook and CMOS . Note, however, that unlike The Bluebook and CMOS , SLR does not use en dashes (that is, “–”). Where en dashes are suggested by The Bluebook or CMOS , hyphens are the appropriate substitute (including in quotations, see RB 5.4).

Hyphens are generally used in compound words and names and in word division; they also are used to separate numbers and indicate number ranges. But see BB 3.2(d). Em dashes are generally used to set off an amplifying or explanatory element in a sentence (for example, “It was a revival of the most potent image in modern democracy—the revolutionary idea.”).

There are no spaces before or after em dashes or hyphens. Examples :

Remove any spaces around em dashes or hyphens in quoted material without comment. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 22.6: Hyphens and Dashes

correct_examples: Correct : Most law students—but not all—study for exams.
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : Some law students — but not those at Stanford — sit in the sun all day.

section_22_7.full_rule_text:
22.7: The One-Space Rule

SLR always uses only one space after periods, colons, or semicolons. This includes quoted material: Where such material uses two spaces, replace with one space and do not indicate it as an alteration. See RB 5.4.
rule_paragraphs: 22.7: The One-Space Rule

SLR always uses only one space after periods, colons, or semicolons. This includes quoted material: Where such material uses two spaces, replace with one space and do not indicate it as an alteration. See RB 5.4.

regex_patterns.description: Single space after period (correct SLR style)

section_22_8.full_rule_text:
22.8: Nonbreaking Spaces

Insert a nonbreaking space (Option+Space on a Mac; Ctrl+Shift+Space on a PC) between a symbol and its corresponding numeral. This is done so that a line break will never separate a symbol from its associated numeral. This most often comes up when using § and ¶. Examples :

Additionally, the following are cases where there should always be a nonbreaking space (represented below by the # symbol):

(3) # the spirit of White Hart Lane endures.

There should not be a nonbreaking space between a volume number and the name of a work. Example :

correct_examples: Correct : The United States Code has many important sections, and a quite important one is 42 U.S.C. § 1983.

Example : Many reasons exist why Tottenham Hotspur will win the Champions League: (1) # Mauricio Pochettino is the best manager in Europe; (2) # Harry Kane scores when he wants; and (3) # the spirit of White Hart Lane endures.
Example : 10:28 # AM MDT.
Example : Ygritte # v. Snow, 353 F. Supp. 3d 837 (D.N.D. 2018).

Example : “Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull # . # . # . for life to go on in the common way.” Example : Ygritte , 353 F. Supp. 3d at 854 (“You know nothing, Jon # . # . # . # .”).

Examples : Part # III.B; Figure # 8; Table # 11; Title # IX; Proposition # 8. Examples : The Federalist No. # 10 ; section # 101; Exhibit # B; notes # 78-83. Examples : No. # 88-cv-01028; U.S. Const. art. # II, § # 2, cl. # 2.
incorrect_examples: Incorrect : The United States Code has many important sections, and a quite important one is 42 U.S.C. § 1983.

section_22_9.full_rule_text:
22.9: Dates and Date Ranges

Retain all digits when giving a range of years (for example, “1993-1998,” not “1993-98”).

When referring to decades, do not insert an apostrophe (for example, “1780s,” not “1780’s”). See RB 22.2.

References to centuries should be spelled out in lowercase (for example, “twentieth century,” not “20th century”).
rule_paragraphs: 22.9: Dates and Date Ranges
Retain all digits when giving a range of years (for example, “1993-1998,” not “1993-98”).
When referring to decades, do not insert an apostrophe (for example, “1780s,” not “1780’s”). See RB 22.2.
References to centuries should be spelled out in lowercase (for example, “twentieth century,” not “20th century”).

section_22_10.full_rule_text:
22.10: Capital Letter After a Colon

SLR follows a straightforward rule to determine whether to capitalize the first word after a colon: Capitalize if the word is a proper noun or the start of a complete sentence. Contra CMOS 6.63. Examples :
rule_paragraphs: 22.10: Capital Letter After a Colon

SLR follows a straightforward rule to determine whether to capitalize the first word after a colon: Capitalize if the word is a proper noun or the start of a complete sentence. Contra CMOS 6.63. Examples :

section_22_11.full_rule_text:
22.11: Doctrine of Patently Asinine Results

If following any citation or usage rule would create a patently asinine result, leave a comment for your SE.

Example :
rule_paragraphs: 22.11: Doctrine of Patently Asinine Results
If following any citation or usage rule would create a patently asinine result, leave a comment for your SE.
Example :
correct_examples: Clark Packard, Congress Should Take Back Its Authority over Tariffs , Foreign Pol’y: Elephants Room (May 4, 2019, 4:19 PM), https://perma.cc/5GBS-Q5K2 [SE: The name of the blog is “Elephants in the Room.” I think we should retain “in the” even though RB 18.3 says to drop it. “Elephants Room” sounds asinine and breaks the idiom.] .

section_1_14.full_rule_text:
1.14: Added Alterations and Retained Emphasis

SLR never uses (alteration added) or (emphasis in original) parentheticals. No indication is necessary to show that an alteration to quoted text is added or that emphasis in quoted text is present in the original.
rule_paragraphs: 1.14: Added Alterations and Retained Emphasis

SLR never uses (alteration added) or (emphasis in original) parentheticals. No indication is necessary to show that an alteration to quoted text is added or that emphasis in quoted text is present in the original.
