section_16_2.section_title: Open-Access Journals and Certain Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals
section_16_2.rule_summary: 16.2: Open-Access Journals and Certain Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals
section_16_2.full_rule_text:
16.2: Open-Access Journals and Certain Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals

Many open-access scientific journals ( PLOS One, Nature Commc’ns, Sci. Advances , and others) publish large volumes of papers, identified with an electronic location identifier instead of a traditional printed page range. In many cases, each of these articles will be individually paginated, so that they each begin on page one. For these articles, place the electronic identifier where the traditional page range would appear, and provide an “at” pincite to the page of the cited material. Example :

If the articles do not have an electronic location identifier, but are instead individually numbered, follow the above instructions but substitute “art.” and the article number for the electronic identifier. Example :
rule_paragraphs: 16.2: Open-Access Journals and Certain Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals

Many open-access scientific journals ( PLOS One, Nature Commc’ns, Sci. Advances , and others) publish large volumes of papers, identified with an electronic location identifier instead of a traditional printed page range. In many cases, each of these articles will be individually paginated, so that they each begin on page one. For these articles, place the electronic identifier where the traditional page range would appear, and provide an “at” pincite to the page of the cited material. Example :

If the articles do not have an electronic location identifier, but are instead individually numbered, follow the above instructions but substitute “art.” and the article number for the electronic identifier. Example :
correct_examples: Heng-Xing Zou, Alison E. Anastasio & Catherine A. Pfister, Early Succession on Slag Compared to Urban Soil: A Slower Recovery , 14 PLOS One e0224212, at 2 (2019), https://perma.cc/C44W-X2Z5.
Kelly Cleland, State of Emergency Contraception in the U.S., 2018 , 3 Contraception & Reprod. Med. art. 20, at 2 (2018), https://perma.cc/W5PQ-TL2Y.

regex_patterns.description: Pincite reference to page or page range

section_16_1.full_rule_text:
16.1: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines

A nonconsecutively paginated journal is a journal in which each issue starts on page one. A consecutively paginated journal has each volume start on page one, but each issue starts where the previous one left off.

For every periodical, you must check whether it is consecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.4, or nonconsecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.5. To check, find the periodical on a library database or the periodical’s website, pull up all issues from the same year or volume as the cited source , and see whether each issue starts on page one. The pagination schemes of some journals do change over time, so it is important to check the year or volume in which the cited source appears.

Once you confirm that a periodical is consecutively or nonconsecutively paginated, please note your findings in the Sourcepull spreadsheet so that future editors do not have to replicate the process.
rule_paragraphs: 16.1: Nonconsecutively Paginated Journals and Magazines

A nonconsecutively paginated journal is a journal in which each issue starts on page one. A consecutively paginated journal has each volume start on page one, but each issue starts where the previous one left off.

For every periodical, you must check whether it is consecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.4, or nonconsecutively paginated, and thus falls under BB 16.5. To check, find the periodical on a library database or the periodical’s website, pull up all issues from the same year or volume as the cited source , and see whether each issue starts on page one. The pagination schemes of some journals do change over time, so it is important to check the year or volume in which the cited source appears.
Once you confirm that a periodical is consecutively or nonconsecutively paginated, please note your findings in the Sourcepull spreadsheet so that future editors do not have to replicate the process.

section_16_3.section_title: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles
section_16_3.rule_summary: 16.3: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles
section_16_3.full_rule_text:
16.3: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles

If an online version of a newspaper or magazine is available, SLR uses an internet citation under BB 18.2.2 (as amended by RB 18 below), not a citation to the print copy of the newspaper or magazine. If for some reason it appears that a print copy is preferable, please flag the issue for your SE.

To clarify, the effect of this rule is that BB 16.6 is rarely used for newspapers and BB 16.5 is generally used only for journals, except for older sources that lack an online equivalent.
rule_paragraphs: 16.3: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles

If an online version of a newspaper or magazine is available, SLR uses an internet citation under BB 18.2.2 (as amended by RB 18 below), not a citation to the print copy of the newspaper or magazine. If for some reason it appears that a print copy is preferable, please flag the issue for your SE.
To clarify, the effect of this rule is that BB 16.6 is rarely used for newspapers and BB 16.5 is generally used only for journals, except for older sources that lack an online equivalent.

deviations_from_bluebook.text: If an online version of a newspaper or magazine is available, SLR uses an internet citation under BB 18.2.2 (as amended by RB 18 below), not a citation to the print copy of the newspaper or magazine.

major_deviations.deviation: Instances where The Redbook contradicts The Bluebook or The Chicago Manual of Style are marked in red font throughout this document.

major_deviations.title: URLs
major_deviations.deviation: In all citations to internet sources, SLR includes an archival link. Contrary to BB 18.2.1(d), SLR never includes both an original and an archival link.

major_deviations.title: Dates and Times
major_deviations.deviation: SLR never uses “last visited” parentheticals. When you encounter a source without any date/time information, please insert an “archived” parenthetical but leave the date blank.

major_deviations.title: Movies
major_deviations.deviation: Contrary to BB 18.6, SLR includes the director(s) rather than the production company in citations to films. Citations should follow the general format of: [ Movie Title ([Director’s Name] dir., [year]). See generally Rafi Reznik, Essay, The Auteur as Editor , 73 Stan. L. Rev. Online (2020). Example :

major_deviations.title: Hyphenation
major_deviations.deviation: Contrary to BB 17.2.4, SLR closes “email,” including in citations.

major_deviations.title: Hyphenation
major_deviations.deviation: Contrary to CMOS , SLR always closes “decisionmaking,” “policymaking,” “treatymaking,” and like terms whether they are used as nouns or adjectives.

major_deviations.title: Hyphens and Dashes
major_deviations.deviation: Note, however, that unlike The Bluebook and CMOS , SLR does not use en dashes (that is, “–”). Where en dashes are suggested by The Bluebook or CMOS , hyphens are the appropriate substitute (including in quotations, see RB 5.4).

major_deviations.title: Capital Letter After a Colon
major_deviations.deviation: SLR follows a straightforward rule to determine whether to capitalize the first word after a colon: Capitalize if the word is a proper noun or the start of a complete sentence. Contra CMOS 6.63.

major_deviations.title: Abbreviating Professional Degrees
major_deviations.deviation: Contrary to CMOS 10.21, SLR does not omit periods in educational degrees. Use "J.D." instead of "JD" and "Ph.D." over "PhD" (and so on).

major_deviations.title: Parallel Citations for Court Filings
major_deviations.deviation: Contrary to BB 10.8.3, pincites to an electronic database should be included only if either (1) the pagination of the format-preserving version differs from the star pagination or (2) the format-preserving version is unavailable.

major_deviations.title: Preferred Sources for Unreported Cases
major_deviations.deviation: SLR does not cite services. See BB 19.

major_deviations.title: Public Domain
major_deviations.deviation: SLR does not use public domain citation formats. Any BB rule requiring a public domain citation (for example, BB Table T1.3 specifications for Vermont court citations) should not be observed.

major_deviations.title: Short Forms for Statutes
major_deviations.deviation: However, SLR does not use a short form version (other than id. ) that omits the title number or statute name.

major_deviations.title: Federal Register Dates
major_deviations.deviation: Contrary to the implication of BB 14.2(a), use the date that appears at the top of the page of the Federal Register rather than the date on which a rule was promulgated or a notice announced.

major_deviations.title: Et al.
major_deviations.deviation: For sources of all types except amicus briefs, see RB 10.5, the first citation should include the full names of all authors, editors, and translators instead of being abbreviated with “et al.” Contra BB 15.1(b), 15.2(a), (b). If the list seems unwieldy, leave a comment for your SE.

major_deviations.title: Subtitles
major_deviations.deviation: SLR always includes subtitles. This applies to all types of sources and deviates from the portion of BB 15.3 that encourages the omission of subtitles.

major_deviations.title: Preferred Versions of Common Works and Special Citation Forms
major_deviations.deviation: By SLR convention (and contrary to BB 15.10.1, ex. 8), a supra short-form citation to a Federalist essay should be formatted as follows:

major_deviations.title: Works in a Collection
major_deviations.deviation: SLR ’s preference is to use “ in ” for all works published in a collection—regardless of whether the collected material was originally published elsewhere.

major_deviations.title: Online Versions of Newspaper or Magazine Articles
major_deviations.deviation: If an online version of a newspaper or magazine is available, SLR uses an internet citation under BB 18.2.2 (as amended by RB 18 below), not a citation to the print copy of the newspaper or magazine.

forbidden_practices.note: Do not use public domain format

T2.Foreign Jurisdictions: Table T2 content is available online at the Bluebook website (jurisdiction-specific citation formats for non-U.S. jurisdictions):contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

Court Names.Court of General/Special Sessions: Ct. Gen. Sess. / Ct. Spec. Sess.

Explanatory Phrases.affirmed by an equally divided court: aff'd by an equally divided court

Selected Services (with abbreviation, pu.United States Tax Cases (bound in Fed. E: U.S. Tax Cases – see other reporters

rule_5.title: Quotations
rule_5.description: Complete extraction of Rule 5 (Quotations) from the Bluebook

sub_rules.title: Formatting of Quotations
sub_rules.text: Quotations of fifty or more words should be formatted as block quotations (indented and without quotation marks). Shorter quotations remain in-line with quotation marks. When using a block quotation, maintain the original formatting, including internal quotation marks. Use an ellipsis to indicate omitted material and brackets to indicate changes or additions.

block_quote_threshold.description: Quotations of 50+ words must be block quoted

sub_rules.title: Alterations and Quotations Within Quotations
sub_rules.text: Indicate any alteration to a quoted text with brackets, including added or changed letters or words. Use "[sic]" after an error in the original that is being preserved. When quoting text that itself contains a quotation, alternate between double and single quotation marks (with the outermost quotes determined by the context of your quote).

sic_usage.description: Indicates error or misspelling in original

sub_rules.title: Omissions
sub_rules.text: Use an ellipsis ("...") to indicate omitted material within a quotation. Do not begin a quote with an ellipsis if the quoted material starts midsentence; simply begin with a lowercase letter (bracketed if needed). Ensure the omission does not alter the fundamental meaning of the quoted text.

meaning_preservation.requirement: omission must not alter fundamental meaning

sub_rules.title: Placement of Punctuation Marks
sub_rules.text: When a punctuation mark is present in the underlying material but not intended to be part of the quotation, the punctuation mark should be omitted if it comes at the end of a quotation and should be included if it comes at the beginning of a quotation. See BB 5.1.

punctuation_at_end.condition: punctuation present in material but not part of quote

punctuation_at_beginning.condition: punctuation present in material but not part of quote

example_1.original: The court stated: 'Justice must be served.'

sub_rules.title: Block Quotes
sub_rules.text: SLR follows BB 5.1 in using block quotes for quotations of fifty or more words. As BB 5.1(a) suggests, it is often permissible to avoid a block quote by simply not quoting extraneous language (e.g., starting and ending a quote in the middle of a sentence), and you should do so when possible. But do not rewrite quotes just to avoid block quoting, and do not try to sneak in a forty-nine-word quotation to avoid a block quote when a longer quote would provide essential context.

restrictions.do_not_use_forty_nine_words: when longer quote provides essential context
restrictions.emphasis: integrity of quotation matters more than avoiding block quote

word_count_guidance.note: word count does not include citations within quotation

sub_rules.title: Omissions from Quotations
sub_rules.text: Use an ellipsis ( . . . ) to indicate the omission of one or more words from the middle of a quoted sentence. Do not use an ellipsis at the beginning of a quotation (even if the beginning of the sentence is omitted) or at the end of a quotation (even if the end of the sentence is omitted) unless what follows in the sentence is also omitted. If one or more full sentences are omitted from the quotation, use an ellipsis that includes end punctuation (e.g., ". . . ."). Leave a space before and after each period in the ellipsis. Do not omit punctuation before or after the ellipsis unless it is a comma that serves only to indicate a series of items. See BB 5.3–5.4.

ellipsis_format.spacing: space before and after each period

beginning.note: even if beginning of sentence omitted

end.exception: if what follows in sentence is also omitted

punctuation_handling.exception: comma serving only to indicate series of items

sub_rules.title: Alterations to Quotations
sub_rules.text: Use brackets to indicate any alterations to the text of a quotation, including altered capitalization, added or changed emphasis, or added footnote call numbers. See RB 1.13; BB 5.2. Use "[sic]" to indicate any obvious errors or misprints in the original quotation that you cannot correct (but for minor errors, consider paraphrasing instead). Do not use "[sic]" to indicate an alternate but still correct spelling (e.g., alternate spelling of a word ending in "-ize" or "-yze"). See RB 24.1.

emphasis.note: or use brackets with emphasis indicator

sub_rules.title: Textual Citations Within Quotations
sub_rules.text: In general, citations within quotations should be omitted unless particularly relevant. Original source: The Court specified "with all deliberate speed," Brown II, 75 S. Ct. at 757, but that phrase is not a model of clarity. Article: As one commentator noted, "The Court specified 'with all deliberate speed,' but that phrase is not a model of clarity."373 373. Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, One Thousand and One Galley Nights, 76 STAN. L. REV. 1789, 1895 (2023) (citation omitted) (quoting Brown v. Bd. of Educ. (Brown II), 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955)). If the quoted citation is particularly relevant and must be retained, it should appear as it does in the quoted source—including, unfortunately, any Bluebooking errors.

retention.include_errors: yes - preserve any Bluebooking errors from original

parenthetical_use.purpose: indicates citations were removed from quote

with_citation_in_original.original_text: The Court specified "with all deliberate speed," Brown II, 75 S. Ct. at 757, but that phrase is not a model of clarity.
with_citation_in_original.edited_text: As one commentator noted, "The Court specified 'with all deliberate speed,' but that phrase is not a model of clarity."
with_citation_in_original.footnote: Collin Fredricks & Catherina Y. Xu, One Thousand and One Galley Nights, 76 STAN. L. REV. 1789, 1895 (2023) (citation omitted) (quoting Brown v. Bd. of Educ. (Brown II), 349 U.S. 294, 301 (1955))

block_quotation_rules.definition: Quotation formatted as indented block without quotation marks

content_rules.citations: may be omitted unless particularly relevant

inline_quotation_rules.definition: Quotation incorporated into sentence with quotation marks

standard_ellipsis.spacing: space before and after each period
standard_ellipsis.usage: omission of material within or between sentences

sentence_end_ellipsis.spacing: space before and after each period
sentence_end_ellipsis.usage: omission of one or more complete sentences

beginning_omission.method: simply start quote with lowercase letter
beginning_omission.bracketing: bracket the lowercase letter if needed

ending_omission.exception: use ellipsis if what follows in sentence is also omitted

sic_specification.purpose: preserve and flag error from original
sic_specification.restriction: do not use for alternate correct spellings

placement_at_end.rule: if punctuation in source but not part of quote, omit from end of quotation

placement_at_beginning.rule: if punctuation in source but not part of quote, include at beginning

preservation.commas_in_series: omit only if comma serves only to indicate series

citations_within_quotes.method: remove from quote, place in parenthetical or footnote
citations_within_quotes.if_retained: preserve exactly as in original, including errors

citation_placement.after_citation: place cite or parenthetical after quotation

quotation_marks_nesting.rule: continue alternating for additional levels of nesting

block_quote_detection.description: Detects indented text (10+ spaces) as potential block quote

inline_quotation.description: Matches text within double quotation marks

single_quotation_nested.description: Matches text within single quotation marks

ellipsis_three_periods.description: Matches three periods with or without spaces

ellipsis_four_periods.description: Matches four periods for sentence-end omission

citation_in_quote.description: Matches likely citations within quoted material

capitalization_alteration.description: Matches single capitalized letter in brackets

word_count_approximation.description: Helps identify quotation boundaries for word counting

alteration_best_practices: Use [sic] sparingly - only for significant errors
omission_best_practices: Avoid ending quotation with ellipsis unless necessary
Preserve meaning - never distort with omissions
Use four-period ellipsis for complete sentence omissions
citation_best_practices: Omit citations within quotations unless particularly relevant
Include full citation in footnote or parenthetical after quote
Preserve original citations if essential to meaning

rule_7_numerals.json.description: Comprehensive extraction of all Bluebook rules regarding numerals, symbols, numbers, ordinals, ranges, section symbols, and formatting conventions

primary_rule.title: Numerals and Symbols
primary_rule.content: In text, spell out numbers zero through ninety-nine, and any number that begins a sentence. Use numerals for 100 and above. In citations, use numerals for all numbers (e.g., "115 F.3d 123"). Use symbols (like § and ¶) as appropriate in citations, but in text, use words ("section" or "paragraph") unless referring to a specific section symbol as a symbol.

rules: Spell out numbers zero through ninety-nine
Spell out any number that begins a sentence
Use numerals for 100 and above
Use words like 'section' or 'paragraph' instead of symbols
Use numerals for all numbers (e.g., '115 F.3d 123')
Use symbols (§ and ¶) as appropriate
Do not spell out numbers in citations

rule_3_3.title: Sections and Paragraphs
rule_3_3.content: Many legal documents, statutes, and regulations are divided into sections (§) or paragraphs (¶). When citing such subdivisions, use the appropriate symbol followed by the number (without a period). If citing multiple sequential sections, use a double section symbol ("§§"). For nonconsecutive sections, separate by commas.

format_rules: Use § followed by number without a period

rule_12_1.title: Basic Citation Forms for Statutes
rule_12_1.content: The basic form for statutes: [Official Name of Act], [published source] [section symbol and number] ([year]). If the act is commonly known by a name, use that name.

details.section_usage: Always include section symbol (§) with statute citations

rule_12_2.title: Choosing the Proper Citation Form
rule_12_2.content: Use the official code if available (e.g., U.S.C. for federal statutes). If a statute is spread across multiple code sections, cite as a range (e.g., 42 U.S.C. §§ 9601-9675). If the statute is not in the code yet, cite the session law. If an unofficial code is more up-to-date or commonly used in practice, you may use it in court documents (with an indication of currency or year). In law review, typically stick to official codes whenever possible.

key_points: Use range format for multiple sections
Use double section symbol (§§) for ranges

examples: There are five elements to the claim.
The statute applies to 115 different violations.

special_cases.rule: Always spell out, regardless of number

notes: All numbers in citations use numerals regardless of magnitude
This applies to case citations, statute citations, page numbers, etc.

section_symbol.name: Section symbol
usage: Cite constitutional provisions: U.S. Const. art. III, § 2
rules: Use § followed by number without period
Use §§ for multiple sequential sections
Do NOT use 'section' or 'sec.' when § is used
In text (non-citation): use 'section' word instead

paragraph_symbol.name: Paragraph symbol
usage: Used in court documents and practice materials
rules: Use ¶ followed by number
Use ¶¶ for multiple sequential paragraphs
In text: use 'paragraph' or 'para.' instead

notes: Do NOT use hyphens (-) for ranges
En-dash is the proper typographic mark

sequential_numbering.rule: For multiple sequential items, use double symbol

format_rules: Spell out in formal text if appropriate
monetary_amounts.note: While not explicitly detailed in Bluebook Rule 6.2, monetary amounts follow standard number formatting rules

format_options: In citations and formal contexts: use numeral with %
percentages.note: While not explicitly detailed in Bluebook Rule 6.2, percentages follow standard number formatting rules

formatting: In text (below 100): spell out ordinals (first, second, third...)
In text (100+): use numerals with ordinal suffix (101st, 225th)
In citations: use ordinals as needed (12th Circuit, 5th Amendment)

rule_7.title: Italicization for Style and in Unique Circumstances
rule_7.content: Words may be italicized in text for emphasis or stylistic purposes, but use this sparingly. In legal writing, certain terms are traditionally italicized: words used as words, foreign words not commonly used in English, and letters or numerals referenced as such.
italicize_numerals_when: Referring to letters or numerals as themselves (e.g., 'the numeral 5', 'the letter a')
Discussing the form or appearance of the number/symbol
Using as a word itself: 'The 's' in statutes is important'

rule_6_1.title: Abbreviations
rule_6_1.content: Use standard abbreviations for case names (table T6), institutional author names (T7), periodical titles (T10), publishing terms (T8), and geographical terms (T10). Do not abbreviate words in textual sentences (except widely known acronyms), but always abbreviate as shown in tables when in citations.

years.full_dates: Use when decision date is essential

spacing.rule: Use nonbreaking space between symbol and numeral
spacing.technical_note: Use Option+Space on Mac; Ctrl+Shift+Space on PC

metadata.note: This comprehensive extraction consolidates Rule 6.2 (Numerals and Symbols) as the primary rule with related rules and formatting conventions for numbers, symbols, and ranges

rule_9_titles.json.title: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court
rule_9_titles.json.overview: Capitalize the titles of judges and officials when used before a name ('Chief Justice Marshall') or when referring to a specific person ('the President'). Do not capitalize when used generically ('any justice may...'). Terms of court (like 'Fall Term') are capitalized when naming a specific term of a specific court. Always capitalize 'Court' when naming the U.S. Supreme Court or when the reference is to the court in a case name in text ('the Court held...'). Otherwise, lowercase 'court'.

before_names.rule: CAPITALIZE when used before a name

specific_person_reference.rule: CAPITALIZE when referring to a specific person

generic_usage.rule: DO NOT CAPITALIZE when used generically

specific_terms.rule: CAPITALIZE when naming a specific term of a specific court

generic_terms.rule: DO NOT CAPITALIZE when used generically

u_s_supreme_court.rule: ALWAYS CAPITALIZE 'Court' when naming the U.S. Supreme Court

court_in_case_name.rule: CAPITALIZE 'Court' when reference is to the court in a case name in text
examples: In Smith v. Jones, the Court held that...

judges_and_officials_titles_table.description: Table T11 from Bluebook - Judges and Officials (Titles) with standard abbreviations

9.1.title: Textual References to Professors
9.1.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
9.1.rule: In text (as opposed to in citations), omit 'Professor' in front of names.

examples.description: If an author has 'Professor' in front of the name in the text, leave it as is

9.2.title: Textual References to Judges as Authors of Judicial Materials
9.2.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
9.2.rule: In text, if a judge is the author of a judicial opinion or other document being discussed, use 'Justice' or 'Judge' (etc.) before their name.

9.3.title: Judges as Authors in General
9.3.section: TITLES OF JUDGES, OFFICIALS, AND TERMS OF COURT
9.3.rule: In text, if a judge is NOT the author of the document being discussed, use just the judge's last name without a title.

examples.wrong: Justice Sotomayor joined the majority opinion...

judges_as_authors.rule: Use title (Justice/Judge) + last name when judge authored the document

judges_not_as_authors.rule: Use only last name, NO title, when judge is not the author

citations.rule: In citations, use proper abbreviations from Table T11

important: Always capitalize 'Court' when referring to the U.S. Supreme Court specifically
The difference between author and non-author references is critical for proper judge citation
Generic references to judges/officials should NOT be capitalized
Terms of court are capitalized only when referring to a specific term (e.g., 'Fall Term 2023')
The context determines capitalization - before a name vs. generic reference
quick_reference: Before a name = CAPITALIZE (Chief Justice Marshall)
Generic = lowercase (any justice, a federal judge)
Judge authored document = Use title (Justice Sotomayor's opinion)
Judge did not author = No title (Sotomayor joined)

rule_9_titles.json.source: Bluebook 21st Edition - Rule 9: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court

rule_17_unpublished.json.overview: Unpublished materials include manuscripts, working papers, dissertations, letters, memos, etc., that are not formally published. Forthcoming sources are those accepted for publication but not yet out. Cite unpublished material by describing it (and if applicable, where on file), and forthcoming by indicating the expected publication.

comprehensive_rules.title: Basic Citation Forms
comprehensive_rules.text: Unpublished: Author, Title (unpublished [descriptor] [year]) (on file with ...). Example: John Doe, Article Draft (unpublished manuscript, 2020) (on file with author). Forthcoming: cite like published but replace year with "forthcoming" and include the journal or publisher if known. Example: Jane Smith, Book Title (forthcoming 2021). If in a journal: ... 123 Harv. L. Rev. (forthcoming 2022).

children.title: Manuscripts
children.text: For manuscripts that are not formally published, provide as much information as possible: Author, Title (date) (unpublished manuscript) and where it is (on file with ... or available at ... if online). If part of a collection, note the collection. Use descriptive parentheticals to clarify the nature (e.g., "draft").

children.title: Dissertations and Theses
children.text: Cite dissertations like: Author, Title (unpublished Ph.D. dissertation, University, year). For LL.M. theses or J.S.D. dissertations, similarly specify. If it's published in Dissertation Abstracts or a database, you could cite that source. But generally treat as an unpublished manuscript with university info.

children.title: Letters, Memoranda, and Press Releases
children.text: These may be cited as: [Author name], [Description] ([Date]) (on file with ...). For example, Letter from John Doe to Jane Smith (Jan. 5, 2020) (on file with the Columbia Law Review). For memoranda or internal documents, similar format, naming the document if it has a title or a brief description. If citing a press release that's not easily found, treat it like a short document: Organization, Press Release, Title (Date) (on file with ...).

children.title: E-mail Correspondence and Listserv Postings
children.text: Cite email like a letter: Email from [Author] to [Recipient] (Date, Time) (on file with ...). If a listserv or forum posting, you can do: [Poster Name], Message, [Name of Listserv] (Date, Time) (on file with ... or URL if archived). Often, if the content is accessible online, one might prefer to cite the online source with rule 18 format.

children.title: Interviews
children.text: For unpublished interviews, cite: Interview with [Name, Title], in [Location] (Date). If you're the interviewer, you could mention that (with author). If a recording or transcript exists, cite that if possible. Example: Interview with John Doe, former Dir., ABC Agency, in New York, N.Y. (May 5, 2020). If the interview is by telephone, you could say (telephone interview).

children.title: Speeches and Addresses
children.text: Cite speeches: [Speaker], [Title of Speech] (Date). If unpublished, maybe (transcript on file with ...). If published in a source, cite that source. If you just have details of the event, include event info: e.g., Speech, Location, Date. Example: Remarks of Jane Doe at the Annual Meeting of the XYZ Ass'n (May 1, 2020).

comprehensive_rules.title: Forthcoming Publications
comprehensive_rules.text: Cite forthcoming journal articles as: Author, Title, [Volume if known] Journal Name (forthcoming Year). For books: ... (forthcoming Publisher Year). If the year is known or likely, use it; if not, you might omit or say (forthcoming). If an article is accepted but volume/issue not assigned, just (forthcoming). If just submitted, treat as a manuscript rather than forthcoming.

comprehensive_rules.title: Working Papers
comprehensive_rules.text: Many working papers (like SSRN drafts) can be cited similar to unpublished manuscripts: Author, Title (Working Paper, Organization Year). If a specific working paper series: Author, Title, ABC Institute Working Paper No. 123 (2020). If available online, you might add a URL parenthetical. The Bluebook generally says to treat them as unpublished unless they have a specific series reference.

comprehensive_rules.title: Electronic Databases and Online Sources
comprehensive_rules.text: If an unpublished or forthcoming source is available online (like a draft on SSRN or an online repository), include the URL and date accessed if required (see rule 18). For example: John Doe, Draft Title (Apr. 2020) (unpublished manuscript), https://ssrn.com/abstract=123456 (last visited Jan. 1, 2021). For forthcoming, you might not have a URL yet, just cite as forthcoming.

comprehensive_rules.title: Short Citation Forms
comprehensive_rules.text: Short cite unpublished sources by last name and a supra note if possible (assuming you gave a full citation in a prior footnote). E.g., Doe, supra note 10. If only one work by Doe is cited, that suffices. If a letter or interview, you might refer to it in text or use an id. if it’s clear. Bluebook doesn’t have special short forms beyond using supra for previously cited miscellaneous sources.

unpublished_materials.description: Materials not formally published, including manuscripts, dissertations, letters, memos, emails, interviews, and speeches

forthcoming_publications.description: Sources accepted for publication but not yet out

working_papers.description: Including SSRN drafts and working paper series

electronic_sources.description: Unpublished or forthcoming sources available online

short_citation_forms.description: How to short cite unpublished and forthcoming sources

rule_19.title: Services
rule_19.overview: Services refer to looseleaf and electronic services that provide compilations of primary law and analysis (like tax services, CCH looseleafs, etc.). These can be cited like books or periodicals depending on how they are organized. Often, they have paragraph or section numbers rather than pages.

subrules.title: Citation Form for Services
subrules.content: Cite the service by name, publisher (if helpful), and pinpoint. Many services have preferred abbreviations. For example: 5 CCH Cons. Fin. Guide ¶ 72,205 (2019). Here, volume 5 of the Commerce Clearing House Consumer Finance Guide, paragraph 72,205. If the service is electronic, indicate the database (e.g., Westlaw) if needed. If the service is organized by release, you might cite release or issue.
key_points: Cite by service name, publisher (if helpful), and pinpoint
Many services have preferred abbreviations (see T15)
Use paragraph (¶) or section (§) numbers rather than pages
For electronic services, indicate database (e.g., Westlaw) if needed
If organized by release, cite release or issue information

examples.explanation: Volume 5 of Commerce Clearing House Consumer Finance Guide, paragraph 72,205, published in 2019

subrules.title: Short Citation Forms
subrules.content: Short cite services by name (if unique) and paragraph/section. E.g., CCH Cons. Fin. Guide, supra note 10, ¶ 72,205. Or simply Id. if immediately previous. Services often have continuous updates, so ensure the supra still points to the same material (services can update paragraph numbers, but assume static).
key_points: Short cite by service name (if unique) and paragraph/section
Use 'supra' with the note number for previously cited services
Use 'id.' if the service was cited in the immediately preceding footnote
Example: CCH Cons. Fin. Guide, supra note 10, ¶ 72,205
Ensure that a supra citation still points to the same material
Note: Services can update paragraph numbers; assume they are static for citation purposes

examples.format: CCH Cons. Fin. Guide, supra note 10, ¶ 72,205
examples.explanation: Short form citing a previously-cited service
Short form if the service was cited in the immediately preceding footnote

selected_services.service_name: Affirmative Action Compliance Manual for Federal Contractors

selected_services.abbreviation: AIDS L. & Litig. Rep. (Univ. Pub. Group)

selected_services.service_name: American Federal Tax Reports, Second Series
United States Tax Cases (bound in Fed. Estate & Gift / Std. Fed. Tax Rep.)
selected_services.abbreviation: U.S. Tax Cases – see other reporters

components.volume: Optional; include if the service is multi-volume
components.service_abbreviation: Use preferred abbreviation from T15; include publisher abbreviation in parentheses
components.pinpoint: Use paragraph (¶) or section (§) symbols; services typically use paragraph numbers
components.year: Include in parentheses; represents publication or update year

electronic_services.note: For electronic services, indicate the database (e.g., Westlaw, LexisNexis) if needed

release_organized_services.note: If service is organized by release or issue, cite the release or issue information

multi_volume_services.note: When citing multi-volume services, include volume number before the service name

updates_and_supplements.note: Services have continuous updates; verify that supra citations still point to the same material
updates_and_supplements.caution: Paragraph numbers may change with updates

notes: Use 'supra' with note number for previously cited services
Use 'id.' only if the service was cited in the immediately preceding footnote
Ensure supra citations still reference the correct material in updated services

key_considerations.primary_law_and_analysis: Services typically compile both primary law and analysis
key_considerations.citation_flexibility: Services can be cited like books or periodicals depending on organization
key_considerations.pinpoint_numbering: Services often use paragraph/section numbers instead of page numbers
key_considerations.updates_tracking: Services have continuous updates; verify paragraph numbers remain consistent
key_considerations.preferred_abbreviations: Use T15 for preferred service abbreviations and publisher identifications

rule_20_foreign.json.title: Foreign Materials
rule_20_foreign.json.overview: This covers citation of foreign legal materials. The Bluebook has extensive tables (T2) for specific countries. General rules: use the official source of foreign law if available, in the original language, with an English parenthetical explanation if needed. Provide jurisdiction if not obvious.
key_principles: Use the official source of foreign law if available
Provide English parenthetical explanation if needed
Always indicate jurisdiction unless obvious from context
Use table T2 for country abbreviations and specific formats

20.1.title: Jurisdiction
20.1.description: Always indicate the country (and subdivision like state or province if needed) unless it's obvious from context. Use table T2 for abbreviations.
rules: Indicate country and subdivision (state, province, canton) if needed
Use table T2 for official abbreviations
Provide English title in parenthesis if source is not in English

20.2.title: Non-English-Language Documents
20.2.description: If citing a source in a language that uses the Roman alphabet, cite in the original language, but you may provide an English translation of the title in parenthesis. If language uses a non-Roman alphabet (Chinese, Arabic, etc.), transliterate the title and then parenthesize the English translation.
key_rules: Cite in original language for Roman alphabet languages
May provide English translation of title in parenthesis
For non-Roman scripts: transliterate then translate
Include language or jurisdiction in parenthesis if needed for clarity

20.2.1.title: Documents Appearing in More than One Language
20.2.1.description: If a document is officially published in multiple languages (like some Swiss laws in German, French, Italian), cite the version you are using and can read. If an English version is official or authoritative, you can cite that. If not, cite the original.
guidance: Cite the version you are using and can read
If English version is official, you may cite that
Otherwise cite the original language
May note existence of translations if relevant

examples.example: Cite Quebec law in French even if English version exists unofficially, unless an official English is provided
Some Swiss laws are officially published in German, French, and Italian - cite the version you use

20.2.2.title: Titles and Names of Documents in Languages Other than English
20.2.2.description: Capitalize foreign titles according to the capitalization rules of that language. Italicize case names or titles of books as in English.
capitalization_rules: Follow the capitalization rules of the source language
In French: only first word and proper nouns capitalized
In German: nouns capitalized, other words lowercase unless proper nouns
In Spanish: first word and proper nouns capitalized
formatting: Italicize case names and titles as in English
Provide English translation of title in parenthesis if reader might not understand
20.2.2.example: Loi relative aux sociétés par actions [Law on Joint Stock Companies] (Belgium)

20.2.3.title: Abbreviations in Languages Other than English
20.2.3.description: Use the foreign-language abbreviations as per local convention or table T2. Do not translate abbreviations of source names.
rules: Use foreign-language abbreviations as per local convention
Consult table T2 for standardized abbreviations
Do not translate abbreviations of source names
Provide parenthetical explanation for less-known abbreviations on first use

20.2.4.title: Languages That Do Not Use the Roman Alphabet
20.2.4.description: Transliterate non-Roman scripts. Use the system given in Bluebook table (for example, pinyin for Chinese, Hepburn for Japanese, etc.). Once transliterated, treat as a foreign title (with italicization rules as appropriate).
process: Transliterate non-Roman script using appropriate system
Treat transliterated text as foreign title

20.2.5.title: Citations to Translations of Non-English-Language Documents
20.2.5.description: If you are citing a translation, indicate the translator and that it's a translation. Also, if you quote a translated passage, you might parenthetically credit the translation.
20.2.5.format: Civil Code of Germany, translated in 2 The German Civil Code: As Amended to January 1987, at 123 (Simon L. Goren trans., Fred B. Rothman & Co. 1994)
requirements: Identify the translator
Clearly indicate it is a translation
Include publication information for the translation
For quoted passages, parenthetically credit the translation source

20.3.title: Cases
20.3.description: Cite foreign cases with the case name (if applicable, italicize as in English), the volume/reporter/page (if analogous to common law citation), and the court and date in parenthesis. Many civil law countries use case numbers and dates instead of reporter citations, so adapt accordingly.
20.3.example: Bundesverfassungsgericht [BVerfG] [Federal Constitutional Court] Mar. 3, 2004, 111 Entscheidungen des Bundesverfassungsgerichts [BVerfGE] 307 (Ger.)
guidance: Use the format provided in table T2 for each country
Adapt to specific country's citation style
Distinguish between common law and civil law formatting

20.3.1.title: Common Law Cases
20.3.1.description: Cite as: [Case Name] [year/volume] [Reporter] [page or case number] ([Court abbreviation] [Year]). For example, R. v. Smith, [2001] 2 S.C.R. 42 (Can.). If country uses year in brackets, follow their style.

structure.year_or_volume: Year in brackets [year] or volume number

guidance: Always include jurisdiction if not obvious from reporter
Include country or province as needed
Follow the year in brackets convention if used by that jurisdiction
Use official reporter names and abbreviations from table T2

20.3.2.title: Civil Law and Other Non-Common Law Cases
20.3.2.description: Often no official case name; you might use the parties or a descriptor. Provide docket or decision number if available, court name, date.

structure.court_name: Name of court in original language
structure.decision_number: Docket or decision number if available
structure.reporter: Official gazette or court bulletin reference

examples.example: Conseil d'État [CE] [Council of State] June 27, 2014, Rec. Lebon 312
examples.description: French Council of State format with official publication reference

guidance: Use available references like official gazettes or court bulletins
Consult table T2 for specific country formats
Many civil law countries use case numbers and dates instead of reporter citations
Adapt citation format accordingly to jurisdiction
Always provide enough information to identify the specific case

20.4.title: Constitutions
20.4.description: Cite foreign constitutions by country name and then constitution (in English if known) and pinpoint. Provide year of adoption or amendment if relevant and not clear by context.

examples.example: Constitution of the Italian Republic art. 5

examples.note: Include year if multiple constitutions in history or if relevant

guidance: Always include country name unless obvious from context
Provide English name if known
Use original language name in italics with English translation in brackets if needed
Include year of adoption if relevant and not clear from context
Use article abbreviations consistent with source document

20.5.title: Statutes
20.5.description: Cite foreign statutes by official name (possibly translated in brackets if needed), the promulgation or code information, and date. Civil law countries often use: Law Name (date) (Country). For codes: give the article number and code name.

examples.example: Official Journal citation for official gazette

guidance: Use official name of statute/code
Provide English translation in brackets if needed
Include promulgation date or code article information
Always include country abbreviation in parentheses
Consult table T2 for jurisdiction-specific formats

20.5.1.title: Statutes in Common Law Systems
20.5.1.description: Common law jurisdictions often mirror U.S./U.K. style: Title (Jurisdiction year). Include jurisdiction abbreviation if sub-national (like Ontario or New South Wales).

examples.example: Australian Consumer Law, Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth) sch 2 (Austl.)

components.title: Australian Consumer Law, Competition and Consumer Act

guidance: Use their official compilation or session law citation
Include jurisdiction abbreviation if sub-national
Follow the citation style of that common law jurisdiction
Include schedule or part references as applicable
Use table T2 for country-specific abbreviations

20.5.2.title: Statutes in Civil Law and Other Non-Common Law Jurisdictions
20.5.2.description: Civil law: often use the date and title: e.g., Gesetz über die ... [Act on ...], Oct. 1, 2020, BGBL I at 123 (Ger.). Or the year/number style: e.g., Law No. 100 of 2006 (Japan).

formats.example: Gesetz über die ... [Act on ...], Oct. 1, 2020, BGBL I at 123 (Ger.)

guidance: Provide English description in brackets if title is not self-explanatory
Include publication reference like an official gazette citation
Use date and/or number as per country's format
Consult table T2 for each country's preferred format
Include whether it's a national or regional/provincial law if relevant

20.6.title: Non-English-Language and Foreign Periodicals
20.6.description: Cite foreign journals similar to U.S. journals, but use the original title abbreviation (per T13 for that language) and include an English translation of the title in parenthesis if not obvious.
20.6.example: 20 Revue Internationale de Droit Comparé 25 (1988) (Fr.) ("International Review of Comparative Law")

structure.english_translation: English translation of journal title in parenthesis

guidance: Use original title abbreviation from table T13 for that language
Include English translation of title if not obvious
Format similarly to U.S. journal citations
For article titles in foreign languages: may translate in parenthetical if helpful
Always provide enough information to locate the source

20.7.title: Short Citation Forms
20.7.description: Use id., supra, etc., for foreign sources similarly. If you've given an English hereinafter, use that. Ensure not to confuse foreign sources with domestic ones if similar names.

short_forms.usage: If immediately preceding footnote is exactly the same source
If an English hereinafter was given in initial citation

guidance: Use id. for immediately preceding identical source
Use supra for previously cited sources with note number
If given English hereinafter abbreviation, use that in subsequent cites
Include country abbreviation if needed to avoid confusion with similarly-named domestic sources
Example: BGHZ, supra note 12 (if using abbreviation for German case reporter)
cautions: Do not confuse foreign sources with domestic ones of similar names
Include country if needed for clarity
Ensure reader can easily trace back to full citation

common_law_countries.notes: Year often in brackets; use official reporter abbreviations
Include provincial abbreviation for sub-national laws
Include state/commonwealth abbreviation; use official reporters

civil_law_countries.notes: Use code abbreviations; consult table T2 for specific format
Use official gazette (BGBL); Bundesverfassungsgericht for constitutional cases

civil_law_countries.constitution_format: Constitution of the Italian Republic art. [number]
civil_law_countries.notes: Consult table T2 for statute-specific abbreviations

civil_law_countries.code_format: Código Civil art. [number] (Spain) or C.C. art. [number] (Spain)

civil_law_countries.notes: Use numbered law format; transliterate original language titles

mixed_systems.note: Civil law jurisdiction within common law Canada
mixed_systems.guidance: Follow civil law citation conventions but include Quebec/Que. abbreviation; cite French source unless official English available
Use appropriate reporter abbreviations; follow local citation conventions from table T2

table_t2_references.description: The Bluebook Table T2 provides country-specific citation formats, abbreviations, and sources. Always consult T2 for:
content: Preferred format for constitutions, statutes, and cases
Specific transliteration conventions for non-Roman alphabets

common_mistakes_to_avoid: Failing to include jurisdiction when required
Not following the original language capitalization rules
Confusing foreign sources with similarly-named domestic sources in short cites
Failing to transliterate non-Roman scripts properly
Not providing English translations when helpful for reader comprehension
Using English-language formatting for sources that require specific foreign citation conventions
Failing to consult table T2 for country-specific format requirements

official: Bluebook Table T13 (Foreign Language Periodical Abbreviations)
Constitutional and statutory documents in original language
reference: International Law Reports (I.L.R.) - for compiled cases
Country-specific legal databases and official repositories
Legal reference materials specific to jurisdiction
Official government websites for statutes and regulations

practical_tips.guidance: Always use the official source of foreign law if available, in the original language
When in doubt about clarity, include the country abbreviation - it's better to over-indicate than to confuse the reader
Provide English translations of titles in parentheses when the original title may not be understood by your reader
Once you establish a hereinafter abbreviation for a long foreign source title, use it consistently throughout your document
Before citing any foreign material, consult Table T2 to ensure you're using the correct format for that specific country
Cite sources in their original language even if translations are available, unless an official English version exists
In civil law jurisdictions without case names, clearly identify the court and decision number to allow reader to locate the case

rule_21_international.json.title: International Materials
rule_21_international.json.description: This covers treaties, international cases, U.N. documents, EU materials, and other international law sources. Generally, cite treaties by official U.S. sources if available (U.S.T. or I.A. etc.), or U.N.T.S for multilateral treaties. Cite international cases from the court reporters (like I.C.J. Rep.), and U.N. documents by U.N. document numbers.

basic_citation_forms.title: Basic Citation Forms
basic_citation_forms.content: Treaties: [Agreement Name], [date], [volume] [Reporter] [page]. E.g., Charter of the United Nations art. 2, June 26, 1945, 59 Stat. 1031, 3 Bevans 1153. International cases: [Case Name] ([Year]) [Reporter] [page]. UN documents: U.N. Doc. [symbol] ([Year]). EU regulations/directives: cite Official Journal (e.g., 2016 O.J. (L 119) 1).

non_english_language_documents.title: Non-English-Language Documents
non_english_language_documents.content: For treaties or international agreements in a language other than English, if there is an official English translation, cite that if you are writing in English. Otherwise cite the original language title italicized, followed by an English translation in brackets. Use the same approach as foreign domestic laws for language handling. Example: [Russian title] [English title] art. X, Feb. 1, 1995, [citation].

jurisdiction_not_evident.title: Jurisdiction Not Evident from Context
jurisdiction_not_evident.content: If citing an international material where the jurisdiction or context might not be clear (like an international tribunal's decision), clarify by including the name of the tribunal or jurisdiction. For example, for an arbitral award: [Case Name], (ICSID Arb. 2010). Or if citing a national court decision in an international context, mention the country.

21.4.1.title: Name of the Agreement
21.4.1.content: Use the official or popular name of the treaty, if there is one, italicized. If no common name, use a descriptive title. Include parties if necessary for clarity (especially if agreement is bilateral and has no title). For bilateral treaties, you can format as "Agreement between [Party1] and [Party2] concerning [Subject]" if no formal title.

21.4.2.title: Parties to the Agreement
21.4.2.content: If a multilateral treaty, no need to list parties in citation. If bilateral and no official title, naming the parties in a parenthetical or in the description might be done as above. If citing an agreement in an open source like U.N.T.S., listing parties isn't required. In the case of unusual parties (like non-state entities), maybe mention them in the description.

21.4.3.title: Subdivisions
21.4.3.content: If citing a specific part of a treaty, use article or paragraph numbers (e.g., art. IV, para. 2). Many treaties are divided into articles, sections, or paragraphs. Use the English term used in the treaty (Article, Section, Chapter, etc.). Indicate subparagraphs with lowercase letters or numbers exactly as in the text (e.g., art. 5(1)(a)).

21.4.4.title: Date of Signing
21.4.4.content: Include the date the treaty was signed (or concluded). If it was later amended or protocols added, you can indicate in parenthetical if you're citing the amended version. The date goes before the citation to the source. Example: Dec. 10, 1982, 1833 U.N.T.S. 3.

21.4.5.title: Treaty Sources
21.4.5.content: Use official sources: For U.S., U.S.T. (until 1984) or T.I.A.S., etc. For multilateral, U.N.T.S. or regional treaty series. You can list parallel cites if useful (like both U.S.T. and U.N.T.S.). If a treaty not yet in a reporter, cite to a slip or the Department of State website etc., with a parenthetical (not yet in force) if applicable. Also see table T4 for treaty source abbreviations.

21.5.1.title: The International Court of Justice and the Permanent Court of International Justice
21.5.1.content: Cite ICJ cases to the I.C.J. Reports: [Case Name] (Party v. Party), Judgment, [year] I.C.J. [page] ([date]). Similarly for PCIJ: [Case Name] (Ser. A or A/B) No. [no.], at [page] ([year]). Include the type of decision (Judgment, Advisory Opinion, Order) if relevant by using a parenthetical or part of citation as above.

21.5.2.title: European Union Courts
21.5.2.content: Cite European Court of Justice (ECJ) cases by case number and report: Case C-123/04, [Party v. Party], 2005 E.C.R. I-1234. For General Court (formerly CFI): Case T-1/99, [Name], 2000 E.C.R. II-0000. Since 2012, official reporter (E.C.R.) ceased; cite to EUR-Lex or other sources with case number and judgment date: Case C-123/17, Name (Jan. 15, 2018), http... (if needed).

21.5.3.title: European Court of Human Rights
21.5.3.content: Cite ECtHR decisions with case name, application number, and paragraph if pinpoint, plus the year of the decision. Example: Smith v. United Kingdom, App. No. 12345/06, 2010 Eur. Ct. H.R.  (Judgment of July 2, 2010). Alternatively, use the official Reports if available (ECHR series up to 1996; after that, just application no. and date). Some cite as: Smith v. UK, 50 Eur. H.R. Rep. 20 (2010).

21.5.4.title: Inter-American Commission on Human Rights
21.5.4.content: Cite IACHR decisions or reports: Name of Case, Case No. or Report No., Inter-Am. C.H.R., OEA/Ser.L/V/II. Doc. [number], [year]. Or if citing a specific report: Report No. 5/04, Smith (Country), Inter-Am. C.H.R., OEA/Ser.L/V/II.122 Doc. 5 rev.1 (2004). Provide enough info to identify the report and use OAS document numbers where possible.

21.5.5.title: Inter-American Court of Human Rights
21.5.5.content: Cite IACtHR cases by case name (translated if needed), series and number: e.g., Smith v. Argentina, Merits, Judgment, Inter-Am. Ct. H.R. (ser. C) No. 150, ¶ 50 (2001). The series C number is for judgments and series A for advisory opinions. Include paragraph for pinpoint if relevant. Always mention if it's merits, reparations, or advisory, etc., as in the example.

21.5.6.title: International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
21.5.6.content: Cite ITLOS cases by name, case number, ITLOS Reporter and page/year if available. e.g., The M/V Saiga (No. 2) (St. Vincent v. Guinea), Case No. 2, Order of Jan. 20, 1998, ITLOS Rep. 123. If no official reporter, cite to a UN document or print source, or to ITLOS's online report with case number and date.

21.5.7.title: International Criminal Court and Other Tribunals
21.5.7.content: Cite ICC cases by name and case number, including perhaps the type of decision. E.g., Prosecutor v. Lubanga, Case No. ICC-01/04-01/06, Judgment (Mar. 14, 2012). For ICTY or ICTR, use their reporting: e.g., Prosecutor v. Tadić, Case No. IT-94-1-A, Appeals Chamber Judgment (Int'l Crim. Trib. for the Former Yugoslavia July 15, 1999). Generally include court name and chamber if needed, case number, and date.

21.5.8.title: Other International Courts
21.5.8.content: For other international courts (e.g., WTO dispute panels/Appellate Body, Court of Justice of the Andean Community, etc.), use a similar format: case name, body, document number or citation, date. For WTO: cite the report by its WTO document symbol and paragraph if pinpoint, plus date of adoption. E.g., WTO Appellate Body Report, United States – Measures Affecting XYZ, WT/DS###/AB/R (Year).

21.5.9.title: International Cases in National Courts
21.5.9.content: If citing a national court case that deals with international law, cite it as a national case (rule 20 for foreign or just normal if US/UK) rather than as an "international case". The only caveat is if using International Law Reports or similar compilation, you could cite that, but Bluebook prefers original source when available.

international_arbitrations.title: International Arbitrations and Claims Commissions
international_arbitrations.content: For arbitration awards: e.g., [Case Name], Award, [year], [volume] [Reporter] [page]. Many are published in International Law Reports or in specialized reports. If not, cite to an official source or a PDF: e.g., (Permanent Ct. Arb. 2012) with case info. For Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal: use the official reports or ILM if applicable. E.g., Amoco Int'l Finance Corp. v. Iran, 15 Iran-U.S. Cl. Trib. Rep. 189 (1987). Provide tribunal name and date if needed.

21.7.1.title: Verbatim and Summary Records
21.7.1.content: Cite UN meeting records: e.g., U.N. GAOR, 55th Sess., 40th plen. mtg., U.N. Doc. A/55/PV.40 (Oct. 10, 2000). PV stands for procès-verbal (verbatim records). Summary records of committees are indicated by SR. Example: U.N. GAOR, 3d Comm., 72d Sess., Summary Record of Meetings 1-3, U.N. Doc. A/C.3/72/SR.1-3 (2017). Include session, committee, etc., as needed, with UN Doc symbol and date.

21.7.2.title: Resolutions and Decisions
21.7.2.content: Cite UN resolutions: U.N. Security Council Resolution 1441, U.N. SCOR, 57th Sess., U.N. Doc. S/RES/1441 (2002). For GA: G.A. Res. 217A, U.N. GAOR, 3d Sess., U.N. Doc. A/810 (1948). If named, you can include name in parenthesis (e.g., (Universal Declaration of Human Rights)). Always include document symbols and year. For decisions (which are often not numbered like resolutions), give description, session, date, and doc number if applicable.

21.7.3.title: U.N. Reports
21.7.3.content: Cite reports of the Secretary-General or other UN officials as: [Author], [Title], U.N. Doc. [symbol] ([Year]). E.g., Secretary-General, Report on the Work of the Organization, U.N. Doc. A/74/1 (2019). Similarly for committee reports: e.g., Human Rights Comm., Concluding Observations: Canada, ¶ 5, U.N. Doc. CCPR/C/CAN/CO/6 (2015). Always provide the U.N. doc symbol and year.

21.7.4.title: Masthead Documents
21.7.4.content: Masthead documents are those with official U.N. document numbers (like A/--, S/-- etc.). The citation should include that doc symbol as above. Essentially any official UN doc is cited by author or subject, doc symbol, date/year. E.g., Letter from the Permanent Rep. of X to the U.N. to the President of the S.C., U.N. Doc. S/2000/123 (Mar. 1, 2000).

21.7.5.title: U.N. Press Releases and Memoranda
21.7.5.content: Cite press releases by U.N. office and PR number: e.g., U.N. Dep't of Pub. Info., Press Release No. SG/SM/2021 (Jan. 1, 2020). For memoranda or statements, if they are not official documents with symbols, treat similarly or as unpublished: name, description, date. Often they are later in press releases or documents though. If only a press release number is available, use that with date.

21.7.6.title: Adjudicatory Bodies Established by the United Nations
21.7.6.content: This includes things like the UN Administrative Tribunal, UNAT, and others. Cite according to whatever reports they produce. If none, cite as a UN doc if available, or as an international case. Many UN-established bodies (ICTY, ICTR, ICC) already covered in rule 21.5. If citing say a UN internal tribunal: Author v. U.N., Judgment, U.N. Admin. Trib., No. 123 (Year). Provide enough context in the parenthetical if needed.

21.7.7.title: Sales Publications
21.7.7.content: UN sales publications often have a "U.N. Sales No.". Bluebook suggests citing like a book, possibly noting the sales number in parenthesis if needed. Example: U.N. DEP'T OF ECON. & SOC. AFFAIRS, TITLE OF PUBLICATION, U.N. Sales No. E.19.XIII.5 (2019). Usually, though, you can treat it like a report with that info. If widely known by sales number, include it.

21.7.8.title: Yearbooks and Periodicals
21.7.8.content: Cite the U.N. Yearbook or other yearbooks as any serial: e.g., 1995 U.N. Y.B. 120. If referring to specific content, possibly indicate section or chapter. For periodicals like UN Chronicle: format as magazine: Author, Article Title, U.N. Chron., Month Year, at page.

21.7.9.title: Regional Organization Documents
21.7.9.content: Cite EU, OAS, AU, etc., documents similarly: identify organization, body, document number, date. For EU, official journal if published; for OAS, use OEA/Ser.L or OAS Doc numbers. E.g., O.A.S. Charter art. 3, Apr. 30, 1948, 2 U.S.T. 2394. Or for OAS GA resolutions: AG/RES. 2908 (XLVII-O/17) (2017). Use sources from T2 for regions.

21.7.10.title: U.N. Charter
21.7.10.content: Cite the U.N. Charter as: U.N. Charter art. X, ¶ Y. No need for date or treaty series as it's universally known. If you need to reference an amendment, you can parenthetically mention the date of amendment. But generally "U.N. Charter" suffice.

21.7.11.title: U.N. Internet Materials
21.7.11.content: Treat U.N. websites and web publications per rule 18. If a piece of information is only on a website (like a web article on un.org), cite with author (if any) or U.N. agency, title, date (if given), URL (last visited date). But if it's an official document accessible via the UN Official Document System, prefer the document citation as above instead of a URL.

league_of_nations.title: League of Nations
league_of_nations.content: For historical League of Nations documents or treaties, cite League of Nations Treaty Series (L.N.T.S.) for treaties: similar to U.N.T.S format. For League publications or Assembly documents, give the League document number and year, if available. Example: Convention on XYZ art. 1, July 5, 1921, 10 L.N.T.S. 50. Use full titles and L.N. Doc. references for other materials as per any available reference.

european_union.title: European Union
european_union.content: Cite EU legislation (regulations, directives) to the Official Journal (OJ). Format: Council Regulation 2016/679, 2016 O.J. (L 119) 1 (EU). That example is the GDPR. EU cases: (see rule 21.5.2). EU official documents (like COM documents or Green Papers): give document number and date, e.g., COM (2020) 123 final (Jan. 1, 2020). Always include (EU) at end of cite for clarity when needed. Regulations and directives should include year, number, and OJ reference.

council_of_europe.title: Council of Europe
council_of_europe.content: Cite Council of Europe treaties via European Treaty Series (E.T.S.) or Council of Europe Treaty Series (C.E.T.S.). E.g., European Convention on Human Rights, Nov. 4, 1950, Europ. T.S. No. 5. Council of Europe recommendations or resolutions: just provide name and date, and source if in a compilation or website. E.g., Committee of Ministers Recommendation No. R (99) 2 (Feb. 2, 1999).

world_trade_organization.title: World Trade Organization
world_trade_organization.content: Cite WTO agreements (like GATT, GATS, etc.) by name, date, and source (often the Marrakesh Agreement establishing WTO, or U.N.T.S.). e.g., Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization art. IX, Apr. 15, 1994, 1867 U.N.T.S. 154. WTO panel or Appellate Body reports: cite the official WTO citation (DS number, report type, and date of adoption). e.g., Appellate Body Report, United States – Standard for Reformulated Gasoline, WTO Doc. WT/DS2/AB/R (adopted May 20, 1996).

international_monetary_fund.title: International Monetary Fund
international_monetary_fund.content: Cite IMF materials like reports or working papers as you would a book or periodical. E.g., IMF, Country Report No. 20/123: Title (2020). For decisions or publications with volume numbers, use them. If referencing the Articles of Agreement of the IMF: Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund art. V, § 3, Dec. 27, 1945, 60 Stat. 1401. The IMF also has publications like "IMF Staff Papers" which are cited like journals.

other_intergovernmental_organizations.title: Other Intergovernmental Organizations
other_intergovernmental_organizations.content: Cite other IGO documents similar to UN style: identify organization, type of doc, number, date. For example, for the OECD: OECD, Title of Report, OECD Doc. no. (Year). For OAS, African Union, etc., see their document formats. If none, treat as institutional author publications (with name of org as author). For NGOs (non-governmental organizations) like Amnesty International reports, cite like a book or report with the organization as author, title, year.

international_non_governmental_organizat.title: International Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)
international_non_governmental_organizat.content: As above, treat NGO publications as books or reports by the organization. E.g., Human Rights Watch, Title of Report 27 (2020). If an NGO resolution or policy paper has a number, include it in the citation. The Bluebook doesn't have a special format beyond normal for these. If quoting a charter or constitution of an NGO, treat it like an internal document with name and date.

yearbooks.title: Yearbooks
yearbooks.content: Cite yearbooks (like Yearbook of the International Law Commission) by Year, Name, page (if pinpoint). E.g., 2018 Y.B. Int'l L. Comm'n vol. II, pt. 2, at 10, U.N. Doc. A/CN.4/SER.A/2018/Add.1. Provide volume and part if applicable. If citing by UN doc number (as the ILC yearbook has), include that as well.

digests.title: Digests
digests.content: Cite digests of state practice or case law by title and volume. E.g., 8 Digest of United States Practice in International Law 123 (1977). Or Digest of International Cases, No. 15, at 45 (Int'l Ct. 2010). If the digest is organized by year and editor, treat like multi-volume book. The Bluebook rule basically says cite appropriately as either book or serial reference with enough info.

short_citation_forms.title: Short Citation Forms
short_citation_forms.content: Use supra for treaties by short name if previously cited: e.g., U.N. Charter, supra note 1, art. 55. For cases, use id. or case name short form as appropriate (e.g., Case Name, supra note 10, at para. 50). For UN docs and resolutions, you can use supra if it's clear (e.g., Resolution 1441, supra note 5). Always ensure no ambiguity. If multiple treaties or documents, a hereinafter might be used for long titles. E.g., ("UNCLOS") supra. Use id. if the immediately preceding footnote is exactly the same source and context.

treaties: Charter of the United Nations art. 2, June 26, 1945, 59 Stat. 1031, 3 Bevans 1153
Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species art. IV, Mar. 3, 1973, 27 U.S.T. 1087, 993 U.N.T.S. 243
icj_cases: Case Name (Party v. Party), Judgment, [year] I.C.J. [page] ([date])
Permanent Court of International Justice: Case Name (Ser. A or A/B) No. [no.], at [page] ([year])
eu_courts: Case C-123/04, Party v. Party, 2005 E.C.R. I-1234
human_rights: Smith v. United Kingdom, App. No. 12345/06, 2010 Eur. Ct. H.R. (Judgment of July 2, 2010)
Smith v. Argentina, Merits, Judgment, Inter-Am. Ct. H.R. (ser. C) No. 150, ¶ 50 (2001)
international_criminal_court: Prosecutor v. Lubanga, Case No. ICC-01/04-01/06, Judgment (Mar. 14, 2012)
Prosecutor v. Tadić, Case No. IT-94-1-A, Appeals Chamber Judgment (Int'l Crim. Trib. for the Former Yugoslavia July 15, 1999)
un_documents: U.N. GAOR, 55th Sess., 40th plen. mtg., U.N. Doc. A/55/PV.40 (Oct. 10, 2000)
U.N. Security Council Resolution 1441, U.N. SCOR, 57th Sess., U.N. Doc. S/RES/1441 (2002)
G.A. Res. 217A, U.N. GAOR, 3d Sess., U.N. Doc. A/810 (1948)
Secretary-General, Report on the Work of the Organization, U.N. Doc. A/74/1 (2019)
wto: Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization art. IX, Apr. 15, 1994, 1867 U.N.T.S. 154
Appellate Body Report, United States – Standard for Reformulated Gasoline, WTO Doc. WT/DS2/AB/R (adopted May 20, 1996)
arbitration: Amoco Int'l Finance Corp. v. Iran, 15 Iran-U.S. Cl. Trib. Rep. 189 (1987)

international_cases.human_rights: Eur. Ct. H.R., Int'l L. Rep., OEA/Ser.L/V
international_cases.criminal_tribunals: ICC Reports, ICTY Reports, ICTR Reports

un_documents.records: U.N. Doc. [symbol], PV for verbatim records, SR for summary records

special_formatting_notes.italicization: Treaty names and case names should be italicized
special_formatting_notes.pinpoints: Use paragraph marks (¶) for international cases, article numbers (art.) for treaties, and page numbers as appropriate
special_formatting_notes.dates: Include signing/conclusion dates for treaties, decision dates for cases, and publication dates for UN documents
special_formatting_notes.jurisdiction_clarity: Always clarify the court/tribunal when the jurisdiction is not evident from context
special_formatting_notes.translations: Provide English translations for non-English documents when citing the original language title
special_formatting_notes.abbreviations: Use standard Bluebook abbreviations for organizations, courts, and publications (see Table T4 for treaty sources)

cross_references.foreign_materials: See Rule 20 for non-English and foreign domestic sources
cross_references.internet_materials: See Rule 18 for online sources and websites
cross_references.books_and_reports: See Rule 15 for citing institutional publications
cross_references.periodicals: See Rule 16 for journal and magazine articles

rule_1.title: Structure and Use of Citations - Signals

rule_9.title: Titles of Judges, Officials, and Terms of Court

rule_15.title: Books, Reports, and Other Nonperiodic Materials

priority_matrix.description: Rules that override based on source hierarchy. Redbook takes precedence over Bluebook.

punctuation_in_citations.resolution: Use Redbook rules if you're writing for Stanford Law Review

short_forms.redbook_rule: Redbook modifications to short form usage
short_forms.resolution: Redbook modifications take precedence in SLR submissions

parentheticals.redbook_rule: RB 1.1 - ALWAYS requires quoting parenthetical when quoted source quotes another
parentheticals.resolution: Redbook requirement is stricter - always use quoting parentheticals

quotations.resolution: Consult both; Redbook provides additional context and house style

enforcement.SLR_citation_checkers: Must follow Redbook first, then Bluebook
enforcement.law_review_editors: Should check against both but prioritize Redbook
enforcement.authors: When in doubt about format, Redbook (if SLR) takes precedence

key_rules.rule_1_signals: Use signals to organize authorities and show support relationships
key_rules.rule_2_typeface: Proper typeface conventions for citations and text
key_rules.rule_4_short_citations: Id., Supra, and case name short forms
key_rules.rule_5_quotations: Block quotations (50+ words), inline quotations, ellipsis, alterations
key_rules.rule_6_abbreviations: Standard abbreviations for case names, courts, reporters
key_rules.rule_7_numerals: Spell out 0-99 in text, numerals in citations
key_rules.rule_8_capitalization: Specific rules for amendments, acts, court names
key_rules.rule_9_titles: Capitalize titles before names, lowercase when generic
key_rules.rule_12_statutes: Cite by official name, code, section, year
key_rules.rule_15_books: Author, title (italicized), edition if not first, year
key_rules.rule_17_unpublished: Include descriptor, unpublished status, where on file
key_rules.rule_19_services: Cite by service name, abbreviation from T15, paragraph/section
key_rules.rule_20_foreign: Original language preferred, Table T2 for country formats
key_rules.rule_21_international: Treaties, ICJ cases, UN documents, international courts

critical_errors: Signal should not be italicized in citation context
Period after section symbol (§. is wrong, § is correct)
Case names not italicized in Whitepages
warnings: Check block quotation word count (50+ words)
Verify short form references to prior citations
info: Typeface conventions vary between Whitepages and Bluepages
Some local court rules may override Bluebook
International materials require Table T2 consultation
Services may have continuous updates to paragraph numbers

requirements: Case name must be italicized
Must include volume, reporter, and page
Year in parentheses at end
Court abbreviation optional if obvious from reporter
case_citations.example_incorrect: Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113 (at 1973) or Roe v. Wade 410 U.S. 113 (1973)

requirements: Include title number (if applicable)
Include code abbreviation (U.S.C., Cal. Penal Code, etc.)
Include section symbol (§), not words
Include year in parentheses
No period after section symbol
Must be in roman type (NOT italicized)
Space between signal and first citation
Multiple sources with same signal separated by semicolons
Different signal types should use different citation sentences
signals.example_correct: See Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020); accord Brown v. Green, 234 U.S. 567 (2019).
signals.example_incorrect: *See* Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020). or See Smith v. Jones, 123 U.S. 456 (2020), accord Brown v. Green, 234 U.S. 567 (2019).

requirements: Id. only for immediately preceding citation
Supra for previously cited secondary sources (NOT cases)
Case name short form allowed for cases
Capitalization must be consistent
short_citations.restrictions: Do NOT use supra for cases; do NOT use id. if not immediately preceding

block_quotations.word_count_note: Does not include citations within quotation

ellipsis.usage: for omissions in middle of sentence
ellipsis.restriction: NOT at beginning or end unless material after sentence also omitted

case_names.example: *Roe v. Wade* (Whitepages) or Roe v. Wade (Bluepages)

signals.rule: Roman type ONLY (never italicized in citations)
signals.note: Unless used as verb in text

periodicals.example: 110 STAN. L. REV. 1 (Whitepages) or 110 STAN. L. REV. 1 (Bluepages)

warnings.guidance: Count words to verify 50+ word threshold
Check against Table T1 and T2
Verify all required citations are included

before_submission: Check all case names are italicized (Whitepages)
Verify signals are in roman type (not italicized)
Confirm no period after section symbol (§)
Verify short forms (Id., Supra) are properly formatted
Check all citations have years in parentheses
Confirm block quotations are properly indented (50+ words)
Verify all abbreviations follow Tables T1-T16
Check for nested parentheses (should use brackets)
Verify quotes from non-English sources are translated
Check Redbook requirements for SLR submissions
Confirm all foreign citations include jurisdiction
redbook_specific: Ensure quoting parentheticals when source quotes another (RB 1.1)
Verify citing parentheticals are not required (SLR optional)
Check abstracts are not cited (SLR rule 16.5)
Confirm block quote alternatives not used to avoid formatting
Check for proper textual citations within quotations

redbook_overrides.description: Specific rules where Redbook (Stanford Law Review) overrides Bluebook

rule_1_1_parentheticals.bluebook: Optional - citing parentheticals recommended but not required
rule_1_1_parentheticals.redbook: REQUIRED - Must include quoting parenthetical when quoted source quotes another
rule_1_1_parentheticals.impact: CRITICAL - Always check for quoting parentheticals in SLR submissions

redbook: SLR prefers to avoid block quotes when possible (selective quoting allowed)
Do not rewrite quotes just to avoid block quoting
No ellipsis at beginning or end unless middle also omitted
rule_5_quotations.impact: MEDIUM - Apply Redbook guidance when formatting quotations for SLR

rule_16_5_abstracts.redbook: SLR does not cite abstracts - change pincite to introduction/conclusion or ask author
rule_16_5_abstracts.impact: HIGH - SLR-specific rule, must be enforced

capitalization_and_titles.redbook: Additional clarity on judge titles and official titles
